seg.output: On the 5th of December I received your letter full of consolation, from which I understand that it was your wisdom that enabled the cities to agree to keep the faith and to resist the calumnies of the pagans, as Myconius calls them.It is certainly a happy omen, and I know not what divine mercy foreshadows to us in the support of Bernatius, the Baselenses, and the Scaphusians.For it appears to me, unless I am mistaken, that this indicates a solid piety, and a faith which has been accepted by us for not so many years, and which is strengthened by his word, has been rooted more deeply, so that it cannot easily be overwhelmed by any storms of evil.The same thing we experience in the faithful people of the common provinces, who, although they seem to be deprived of the freedom of teaching, and to be oppressed and carried away by the tyranny, yet stand so erect in the midst of their affliction, and do not cease to devise ways of supplying their own ministers, that we may openly see that the word of the Lord, sown in a fruitful land, cannot but produce its fruit.What remains, therefore, seems to have been obtained by the grace of the Lord, namely, the steadfastness of the city of Zurich, which is, in fact, our metropolis.Consider, then, what scandal would arise, if that city, which is powerful in men, order, and authority, and which has been a mother of piety to the other Swiss cities, by supplying them with that pure milk of the restored religion, should be overthrown by the storms of conspiracies and evil arts, and should fall from the rank of the piety which it has so earnestly professed.

seg.output:
I received your letters in the beginning of December full of consolation, from which I understand that it was due to your wisdom that the cities agreed to keep their faith and to ward off the calumnies of the pagans - as Myconius calls them.Indeed, it is a good omen, and I do not know what the Lord's great mercy is pointing to us through Bernatius, the help of the Baselians and Scaphusians.It seems to me, unless I am mistaken, to indicate a solid piety and the same faith we have acknowledged not so many years ago, which is based on his word, has taken its roots deeper than to be easily covered by any storms of evil.The same we experience in the faithful citizens of the common provinces, even though they seem to be lying and even snatched and oppressed by tyranny, deprived of freedom of teaching, yet in the midst of affliction they stand so erect in spirit and do not cease to devise schemes for providing their ministers with their own money, so that we can clearly see that the word of the Lord, which has been sown in a fruitful land, cannot fail to produce its fruit.What remains, then, seems to have been achieved by the grace of the Lord, namely the steadfastness of the city of Zurich, which in fact is our metropolis.Think how great a scandal would arise, if the city, which is powerful in men, in order and in authority, and which, as a pious mother, has given that pure milk of defected religion to the other Swiss cities, were to fall from the degree of accepted and so strongly professed piety, by the storms of conspiracies and evil arts.For what has been conceded to their madness for the time being in that military alliance does not pertain to the reason of that faith, since everyone can see that it was forced and violent, which the cunning of the adversaries then demanded, and thus a thing was done, which usually happens in this kind of deceit, that by the same design they tried to confirm their own position in the alliance and weaken ours, so that by rightly inspecting the head of the alliance we can easily get rid of their deceit and avoid their calumny with the assertion of our own religion.
I read your most careful advice with great pleasure, and since you ask, what I think should be done, I answer that it does not seem advisable to me to take this course at the beginning of the affair, since there is hope that they will see that they cannot attain what they are attempting, especially since the people of our country could be affected in various ways and be excited or alienated in their minds by new arts against us, as those who are eager for novelty and negligent of Swiss freedom.Besides, I hardly persuade myself that it will be so, as you kindly conjecture, that they will easily keep peace on any conditions, when we renounce the alliances.Rather, I would fear that they would use what arts they could to remove the fields from the cities in the pretext of their ancient freedom and the name and glory of the Swiss, which could easily be achieved if they set fire to a few villages and oppressed those who are in the country, who seem already to be ours.

seg.output: I read your advice with great pleasure, and since you asked what I would consider the best course of action, I do not think it would be wise to start the negotiation with the hope that they will clearly see that their efforts will be fruitless. Moreover, they might be affected by various ways and their minds might be stirred or alienated from us as they are eager for new things and negligent of Swiss freedom. Furthermore, I hardly believe it would be the case that they would easily keep the peace with any conditions, as you kindly speculate, when we have renounced the treaties. Rather, I would fear that they would use any means necessary to alienate the lands from the cities under the pretext of preserving the old freedom and the Swiss name and glory, which they could easily achieve if they were to set fire to and trouble some of the villages in the countryside, who are already our own. You know how they recently kept faith with the Senate of Zurich, that is, during the last war, some of the countryside who had not yet been plundered or troubled still dared to leave and make peace with the host and the ignored magistrate. We owe and accept this handsome treaty to their faithlessness. Therefore, first gentler and conciliatory measures should be attempted if they should give way to humanity and grave gentleness.

seg.output: I read your very circumspect advice with great pleasure, and since you ask, I think it would not be wise to take that approach from the outset, when it is likely that they will see that they cannot achieve what they are attempting, especially since our people could be affected in various ways and, being eager for new things and negligent of Swiss liberty, could be stirred up or alienated in their minds by new methods used against us. Furthermore, I hardly think it will be as you optimistically suggest, that if we renounce the treaties they will easily keep the peace under any conditions. Rather, I fear that they would use any means to drive the countryside away from the cities under the pretext of preserving their ancient liberty, the Swiss name and glory, which they could easily do if they set fire to and distress a few districts which already seem to be ours. You know how they recently kept faith with the Zurich Senate, that is, during the last war some from the countryside, before their property had been taken or harmed, yet ventured to withdraw and make a pact with the enemy and in contempt of the magistracy. To speak freely, we owe and accept this fair treaty to their perfidy. Therefore, the first thing to do is to try gentler and more placating methods, should they give way to kindness and a gentle severity. If that cannot be achieved, the next thing, according to fairness, will be to threaten to dissolve the treaties. For us, treaties like this, open to calumny, are not treaties but bonds of denied liberty.

hoc modo calumniis patentia non foedera, sed vincula esse negatae libertatis.Quis scit, an ad has minas fiant tractabiliores?Non enim sunt tam stupidi, quin expendere queant, quid mali illis paritura esset nostra discessio.Quodsi ne hoc quidem consilium posset proficere, tum in hoc esse, quod consulis, nempe nostrae libertatis retinendae gratia foedera illa rescindenda, scilicet interim multa vigilantia de novis ineundis et servandis amicis sociis, de urbium Transrhenanarum et principum christianorum ambienda concordia, de Gallo salutando ac agris privatis hostiatim rogandis, in fidene mansuri, et inibi de caussae genere, nempe hoc esse in foribus, ut non libertatem modo pristinam, sed et fidem primaevam et religionem apostolicam, qua nulla antiquior est, amissuri simus, si foederati paganis esse velimus.Multa sunt, quae pro tuo acerrimo iudicio rectius vides, quam ego monstrare possem.Haec postrema erit et, quod dicitur, sacra ancora.Cura tantum, id quod sedulo facis, ut animis tuorum nihil decedat ad veritatem retinendam.Veniet dies, quae resarciet etiam seculo, quicquid damni clade superiori respublica vestra pertulit.Dives est deus noster et se diligentibus [!] beare etiam regnis assuevit.
De caesare securi estote.De caesare securi estote.Dimisit magnum militum Germanicorum numerum, nec putant illi aliud esse consilii, quam ut primo vere undis se committat Hispaniis reportandum.

seg.output: I highly approve of your very prudent plan and since you ask me what I think should be done, I answer that I do not think it would be wise to begin by taking the course of action you have proposed, because it would be evident to them that they cannot accomplish what they plan to do, especially because our people may be affected in different ways and may become eager for new things or neglectful of Swiss freedom due to the dissolution of treaties.Furthermore, I hardly think it is likely to be as you candidly surmise, that if we renounce treaties, they will easily keep the peace under any conditions.Rather, I fear that they might find ways to separate land from cities widely in the pretext of preserving their old freedom and the name and glory of Switzerland; this would be easily achieved in case of war, with the help of foreigners, if they make their own people suffer from destruction and oppression, which are already in the countryside, and these people seem to be ours.For you know how they have recently been faithful to the Senate of Zurich, that is, during the last war some people from the countryside, without being affected by their own misfortune, had the audacity to leave and make peace with the enemy and the despised government.For this so beautiful treaty we owe them and give them thanks for their betrayal.Therefore, first a more humane and appeasing course of action should be tried, if they give way to humanity and serious meekness.If this cannot be accomplished, then the next thing, according to equity, will be to threaten them, that is, of the dissolution of treaties.For us the treaties will not be treaties of freedom denied, but chains of denied freedom.Who knows if they will be more tractable to these threats?For they are not so foolish not to understand what harm our departure would bring them.If even this plan could not be successful, then there would be what you advise, namely, to rescind the treaties in order to preserve our freedom.Therefore, much vigilance should be taken in making and preserving new friends and allies, in seeking harmony among cities on the other side of the Rhine and among Christian princes, in saluting the French and in asking for private lands in trust, and also, outside, that it is not only the old freedom, but also the ancient faith and the Apostolic religion, which is the oldest of all, that we would lose if we wanted to be associated with pagans.There are many things that you see more correctly than I could show, according to your sharp judgment.This will be the last and, as they say, sacred anchor.Just make sure, as you do with diligence, that nothing is lost among your people concerning the truth.The day will come that will make up, even to this century, whatever damage and loss the Republic suffered from the previous war.Be sure that our God is rich and He is used to reward those who are devoted to Him.Even kingdoms He blesses.

seg.output: On the 5th of December, I received your letters full of consolation, from which I understand that you have been able to convince the cities to remain faithful and to reject the calumnies of the pagans (as Myconius calls them). Indeed, it is auspicious that Bernatius, the Baselians and the Scaphusians have provided us with a sign of the Lord's extraordinary mercy. For, if I am not mistaken, this signifies that the solid piety and faith that we have recognized for not so many years has taken its roots deeper than to be easily overwhelmed by any storms of evil. We also experience the same in the faithful people of the common prefectures, who, although deprived of their freedom of teaching, seem to be lying down and even seized and oppressed by tyranny, still stand up in the midst of affliction with such courage and do not cease to devise ways to support their ministers with their own money, so that we can plainly see that the word of the Lord, sown into a fruitful land, cannot but give its fruits. What remains, then, seems to have been achieved by the grace of the Lord, namely, the steadfastness of the city of Zurich, which is in fact our metropolis. Think, however, what scandal might arise if the city of yours, which is strong with men, order and authority, and which, as a pious mother, has provided the pure milk of the relapsed religion to the other Swiss cities, should fall from the degree of the received and so firmly professed piety by the storms of conspiracies and evil arts!

et quandoquidem rogas, quid equidem agendum existimarem, respondeo: mihi non videri consultum, ut initio negotii ea ratio ineatur, cum quod spes sit futurum ut illi palam cernant, suos conatus assequi non posse, quod moliuntur, tum maxime, quod ad foederum solutionem vulgus nostrum varie affici et novis artibus adversum nos, ceu rerum novarum cupidis et libertatis Helveticae negligentibus, aut excitari aut alienari animis posset.
seg.output: On December 5th, I received your letter full of consolation, from which I understand that it was through your wisdom that the cities agreed to remain faithful and avoid the calumnies of the pagans (as Myconius calls them). Indeed, it was auspicious and some extraordinary mercy of the Lord is indicated to us by the help of Bernatius, Basel and Scaphusian. For it seems, unless I am mistaken, that solid piety and faith, recognized by us for not many years, have grown deeper roots than to be easily overwhelmed by any storm of evils. The same we experience in the faithful people of the common prefectures, who, although they seem to be deprived of liberty of teaching, thrown away and oppressed by the tyranny, yet in the midst of their trouble they stand erect in spirit, nor do they cease to take counsel for their ministers to be maintained by their own means, so as to behold openly that the word of the Lord, sown in the fruitful land, cannot but bring forth its fruit. What then remains, it is thought to be obtained by the grace of the Lord, namely, the constancy of the city of Zurich, which in reality is our metropolis. Consider, I pray thee, what scandal would arise thence, if the city of yours, which abounds with men, order and authority, and which, as a pious mother, has given this pure milk of defected religion to the other Swiss cities, should, upon the rising of conspiracies and storms of wicked arts, fall from its degree of received and so confidently professed piety. For that which was given in that military league for the time to the fury of those, does not appertain to the account of that faith; since it is manifest that the things were framed and forced, which then the subtilty of the adversaries required; and so a thing was done, which usually comes to pass in such kind of frauds, that, with which they attempted to confirm their designs in war, and to weaken ours, we may now, upon a due inspection of that head of the league, easily dissolve the fraud and avoid the calumny with the assertion of our religion. I have read with great pleasure your most circumspect counsel; and since you ask, what I think is to be done, I answer, that it does not seem to me prudent to take such a course at the beginning of the business, that they may plainly see that they cannot effect what they attempt; especially, because the common people of ours may be affected in various manners, and their minds either excited or alienated from us, as desirous of innovations and negligent of the liberty of the Swiss.

seg.output: On the first of December I received your letters full of consolation, from which I understand that your wisdom has been successful in maintaining fidelity and preventing the calumnies of the Pagans (as Myconius calls them). Certainly, Bernatius of Basel and Scaphusia has presaged something auspicious and something of an extraordinary divine mercy. For it appears, if I am not mistaken, that the solid piety and faith that has been known to us for not so many years, has taken its roots deeper than to be easily overwhelmed by any storms of evils. We experience the same in the faithful men of the common prefectures, who, although they seem to have been deprived of freedom of doctrine and lie prostrate and oppressed by tyranny, yet stand erect in the midst of their affliction and do not cease to devise means for providing for their ministers with their own money, that we may visibly see that the word of the Lord, sown in a fruitful land, cannot but bring forth fruit. What remains, therefore, seems to be obtained by the grace of the Lord, namely, the constancy of the city of Zurich, which is in fact our metropolis. Consider, what an offense it would be, if that city, which is of such power, rank, and authority, and which, like a pious mother, has supplied the pure milk of the reformed religion to the other Swiss cities, should fall from the rank of the received and so firmly professed piety, by means of conspiracies and arts of evil. For that which was given in that military league for the time being does not concern the reason of that faith, since no one can deny that it was patched up and forced by the craft of the adversaries, and done according to the custom of this kind of fraud, that what they aimed at, to confirm their own counsels in the war and weaken ours, we may now, by a due consideration of the head of that league, easily dissolve the fraud and avoid the calumny with the assertion of our own religion. I have read with great pleasure your very prudent advice; and since you ask what I think should be done, I answer that it does not appear to me to be good advice to enter upon this affair in such a manner, as if there were hope that they would plainly see that they cannot effect what they attempt; especially, since the people of our country may be variously affected, and have their minds alienated by new arts, as if they were desirous of novelties and negligent of the liberty of Switzerland. Moreover, I hardly believe it will be as you candidly conjecture, that, if we renounce the leagues, they will easily observe the peace upon any conditions; rather should I fear that by what arts they might, under pretense of the old liberty and the name and glory of Switzerland, alienate the lands far and near from the cities, which they could easily effect, if they should set some of their own people, who already appear to be of our side, in those places that are wasted and harassed in the country.

seg.output:
I received your letters on the 1st of December full of consolation, from which I understand that it is due to your intelligence that the cities have agreed to remain faithful and to ward off the slanders of the pagans (as Myconius calls them). It is certainly very auspicious and I do not know what it forebodes, but it seems to me that the assistance of the Bernese, Basel and Scaphusians is a sign of a special divine mercy. For it appears that the solid piety and faith which has been acknowledged by us for not many years now, and which is based on his words, has taken its roots more deeply, so that it cannot be easily buried by any storms of evil. The same is experienced by the faithful men of common governments, who, though they seem to be deprived of the freedom of learning, cast down and even torn away and oppressed by tyranny, yet in the midst of the affliction stand upright in spirit, and do not cease to devise means for sustaining their ministers with their own money, so that we may plainly see that the word of the Lord, when sown in a fruitful land, cannot fail to bring forth its fruit. Therefore, it seems that the grace of the Lord has obtained this, namely, the constancy of the city of Zurich, which is indeed our metropolis. Think, however, how much scandal would have arisen, if the city of your state, which is strong in men and order and authority, and which as a pious mother has provided that pure milk of a lost religion to the other Swiss cities, had fallen from her received and so firmly professed piety through the storms of conspiracy and wicked arts! For what was granted to their fury at that time in that military alliance does not pertain to the matter of the faith; for everyone can see that it was patched together and violently imposed, which the cunning of their adversaries at that time demanded, and that it was done, as is often the case in this kind of fraud, that, by this means they might, on the one hand, confirm their projects in the military alliance, and, on the other, weaken ours; so that now, rightly examining the head of this alliance, we can easily dissolve their fraud and avoid their calumny with an assertion of our own faith.
I have read with great pleasure your most circumspect counsel; and since you ask what I think is to be done, I answer: it does not seem expedient to me to take that course at the beginning of the business, since there is hope that they may plainly see that they cannot attain what they are attempting, especially since the people of our state might be affected in various ways and alienated from us by new arts, as desirous of novelties and negligent of the Swiss liberty. Moreover, I hardly persuade myself that it will be so, as you candidly conjecture; since, if we should renounce the alliance, they would easily keep peace upon any terms; but rather I should fear that by what means soever they might alienate the lands from the cities, under the pretext of retaining their ancient liberty and the name and glory of the Swiss, which they could easily effect, if they should make their own everywhere in the country, after some fields had been laid waste and harassed, which are now ours. For you know how faithful they lately were to the senate of Zurich, that is, in the late war, some of the country, who, before their own goods were injured or afflicted, yet ventured to withdraw themselves and make peace with the enemy, and, I know not, to contemn the magistracy; to whose (to speak freely) perfidy we owe this so specious alliance, and thankfully acknowledge it.

I received your letters on the 1st of December filled with consolation, from which I understand that it was due to your prudence that the cities agreed to remain faithful and to refute the slanders of the pagans (as Myconius calls them). Indeed, it was auspiciously foretold and I think something of divine mercy is symbolized by Bernatius, the help of the Baselians and the Scaphusians. For, if I am not wrong, it indicates that the solid piety and the faith that was not so long ago acknowledged by us has planted its roots deeper, so that it cannot be easily overwhelmed by storms of evil. The same we experience in the faithful people of the common administrations, who, although they seem to be deprived of freedom of doctrine, to be dragged away and oppressed by tyranny, still stand with such erect minds in the midst of affliction and do not cease to take measures for feeding their ministers with their own money, so that we can clearly see that the word of the Lord sown in the fruitful land cannot fail to bring forth fruit.
Therefore, it seems that this has been obtained by the grace of the Lord, namely the constancy of the city of Zurich, which is our metropolis. Think of the scandal that would arise if the city that is so strong in men, in order and in authority, and which, as a pious mother, has provided the pure milk of corrupted religion to the other Swiss cities, should fall from the rank of the received and so strenuously professed piety when storms of conspiracies and evil arts arise! For what has been given in that military covenant for the time being does not relate to the reason of that faith, since everyone sees that it was patched together and forced upon us, which was then required by the cunning of the adversaries, and thus it was done, as is usually the case in this kind of deceit, so that, by properly examining the head of the covenant, we can now easily dissolve the deceit and avert the calumny together with the assertion of our piety.

the pure draught of the restored religion, should, by the storm of conspiracies and evil arts, fall from the degree of the piety which it has so solemnly professed!For that which was conceded to their fury in the military league at that time does not belong to the account of this faith, since it is evident that they were patched up and forced, which the craft of the adversaries then required, and that it was done, as is usually done in this kind of fraud, that by the same counsel which they then used to confirm their designs and weaken ours, we may now, with a right inspection of that head of the league, easily dissolve their fraud and decline their calumny, with the assertion of our religion.But I read with great delight your most circumspect counsel; and since you ask what I think is to be done, I answer, that it does not seem to me to be prudent to take this course from the beginning of the business, that they may plainly see that their attempts are not likely to succeed, especially because the people of our country might be affected in various ways, and their minds alienated or excited to new arts, as being desirous of innovations, and negligent of the Swiss liberty.Moreover, I scarcely persuade myself that it will be so, as you candidly conjecture, that when we shall have renounced the league, they will easily keep peace upon any conditions; but rather, I should fear that by what arts they might give their endeavour, that under the pretext of their old liberty, and of the name and glory of the Swiss, they might alienate the lands from the cities in general, which they may easily do when the war is begun, and foreign aids and garrisons brought in, if they should make their own in many places which are in the country, and which now seem to be ours.For you know what fidelity was lately made to the senate of Zurich, that is, in the last war, by some of the country, who, although their own goods were not yet taken or afflicted, yet had the confidence to withdraw and make peace with the enemy, and, I know not, to contemn the magistracy; of whose perfidy (to speak freely) we owe this so beautiful league, and accept it.Wherefore, the more gentle and placable course is to be first attempted, if perchance they will yield to humanity and grave meekness.If this cannot be obtained, the next way, according to equity, will be to threaten them with the dissolving of the league; for to us the leagues, thus open to calumnies, are not leagues, but bonds of slavery.Who knows but they may be made tractable by these threats?For they are not so stupid but they may consider what mischief would follow our departure.

quin magis id metuerem, quibus possent artibus daturos operam, ut praetextu veteris libertatis et Helvetici nominis atque gloriae retinendae agros passim ab urbibus alienarent, quod quidem bello coepto et alienis adductis auxiliis praesidiisque facile consequerentur, si pagis aliquot exustis et vexatis, qui sunt rure, passim suos facerent, qui iam nostri videntur.Scis enim, quam fidem praestiterint senatui Tigurino nuper, hoc est proximo bello, quidam ex agro, qui rebus suis nondum petitis aut adflictis secedere tamen et cum hoste, nescio et contempto magistratu, pacisci sunt ausi; seg.output: On the first of December I received your letters full of consolation, from which I understand that your prudence has been successful in retaining faith and preventing the calumnies of the pagans (so Myconius calls them).It is certainly auspicious and I believe it is a sign of some extraordinary divine mercy that Bernatius, the Baselians, and the Scaphusians have come to our aid.For they signify, if I am not mistaken, that a solid piety and a faith which we have recognized not so many years ago, and which is based on his word, has taken root more deeply than to be easily overcome by any storms of evil.The same thing is experienced in the faithful men of the common prefectures, who, although they seem to be deprived of the freedom of doctrine, and even snatched away and oppressed by tyranny, yet stand so erect in the midst of their affliction, and do not cease to take counsel for maintaining their ministers with their own resources, so that we may plainly see that the word of the Lord, being sown in a fruitful land, cannot fail to bring forth its fruit.What remains is, that they seem to have obtained this by the grace of the Lord, that is, the constancy of the city of Zurich, which is in effect our metropolis.Think, then, what scandal would arise, if that city, which has strength in its men, its order, and its authority, and which, as a pious mother, has afforded to the other Swiss cities the pure milk of a corrupted religion, should fall from the degree of a received and so earnestly professed piety, by the rising of conspiracies and storms of wicked arts!For that which was granted in that military league for the time being does not belong to the reason of that faith, since everyone must see that it was woven and forced, which the subtlety of their adversaries then demanded, and which is usually done in this kind of fraud, that, by rightly considering the head of that league, we may easily dissolve their fraud and avoid their calumny, with the assertion of our own religion.But I read with great pleasure thy most circumspect advice; and since thou askest what I think ought to be done, I answer, that it does not seem to me a good counsel to take the first method, with a hope that they may plainly see that they cannot effect what they attempt; especially since the people of our country may be variously affected, and their minds alienated or excited towards new arts, as being desirous of novelties, and negligent of the liberty of Switzerland.Moreover, I am hardly persuaded that it will be so, as thou candidly conjectures; that, when we shall have renounced the leagues, they will easily keep peace upon any condition; but rather I should fear, that they might use such arts, that, under the pretext of an ancient liberty, and of the name and glory of the Swiss, they might alienate the fields from the cities, which they might easily do, if they should make their own among those countries which are in the country, and which are already ours, after the fields shall have been burnt and laid waste.For thou knowest how those of the country have lately behaved towards the senate of Zurich, that is, in the last war; for, to speak freely, we owe this fair league to their perfidy, and therefore we accept it.Wherefore the first thing to be tried is a more humane and placable course, if perchance they may yield to humanity and a grave gentleness.If that cannot be obtained, then the next way will be to threaten them with the dissolution of the leagues; for to us these leagues are no leagues, but bonds of slavery, being exposed to calumnies.Who knows but they may be made tractable by such threatenings?For they are not so stupid but they may consider what evil our departure would bring them.And if this counsel should not take effect, then we must do as thou advisest; that is, we must rescind the leagues for the preservation of our liberty; but in the mean time, we must be very careful to take new friends and allies, to make an agreement with the cities beyond the Rhine and the Christian princes, to salute the French, and to ask the private fields to remain in faith, and, there, to consider the nature of the cause; that is, that, if we will be leagued with the pagans, we shall not only lose our ancient liberty, but also our primitive faith, and the apostolical religion, which is of no greater antiquity.

seg.output: On the first of December, I received your letter full of consolation, from which I understand that it was your wisdom that caused the cities to agree to remain faithful and to ward off the calumnies of the pagans (as Myconius calls them).Without doubt, what Bernatius, the Basileensians, and the Scaphusians have done gives us assurance of some extraordinary divine mercy.For it seems to me, unless I am mistaken, that their solid piety and our faith that has been recognized for not so many years, and is based on his word, has taken its roots much deeper than to be easily overwhelmed by any storms of evil.The same we experience in the faithful men of the common prefectures, who, although deprived of the liberty of teaching, seem to lie down, and even be taken away and oppressed by tyranny, yet in the middle of their affliction stand so erect in spirit and do not cease to take counsel for the maintenance of their ministers with their own money, so that we clearly see that the word of the Lord, sown in a fruitful land, cannot fail to bear its fruit.So it appears that what yet remained was obtained by the grace of the Lord, namely the steadfastness of the city of Zurich, which is in effect our metropolis.Consider what scandal would arise from it, if that city, which is strong by its men, order, and authority, and which, as a pious mother, has supplied that pure milk of the restored religion to the other Swiss cities, should be overthrown by the storms of conspiracies and evil arts, and should fall from the degree of piety which it has so earnestly professed!For what has been given for the time to their audacity in that military alliance does not pertain to the consideration of that faith, since every one sees that whatever was then demanded by the craft of our adversaries was patched together by violence, and so was done that which is usually done in this kind of deceit, that, by rightly inspecting the head of the alliance, we may easily dissolve the deceit and avoid the calumny, with the assertion of our religion.I read with great pleasure your most circumspect advice; and since you ask what I deem to be done, I answer, that I do not think it a wise course to take in the beginning of the business, such a course as gives hope that they may plainly see that they cannot accomplish what they aim at; especially since the people of our canton may be variously affected and have their minds either stirred up or alienated by new arts, as being desirous of novelties and negligent of the liberty of Switzerland.Moreover, I can hardly persuade myself that it will be as you candidly conjecture, that, when we shall have renounced the alliances, they will easily keep peace on any conditions; but rather I should fear that, by what arts they could, they would, under pretext of their old liberty and of the name and glory of Switzerland, alienate the lands from the cities in general, which they could easily do when the war is begun and foreign aids and garrisons brought in, if they should make their own people in the country, who already seem to be ours, to suffer by fire and pillage.For you know what faith was kept with the senate of Zurich lately, that is, in the last war, by some of the country, who, though their possessions were not yet seized or afflicted, yet ventured to withdraw and to make peace with the enemy, I know not how, and to despise the magistracy; whose (to speak freely) perfidy we owe this so specious alliance, and acknowledge with thanks.Wherefore, the more humane and placable course should first be tried, if perchance they will yield to humanity and grave meekness.If that cannot be obtained, then the next way, according to equity, will be to threaten them with the dissolution of the alliances; for to us these alliances, thus open to calumnies, are not alliances, but bonds of slavery.Who knows but that they may be made more tractable by these menaces?For they are not so stupid as not to consider what evil would arise to them from our departure.If even this counsel cannot take effect, then there is that which you advise, namely, that the alliances should be dissolved out of regard to our liberty; namely, that, meantime, great vigilance should be used in making and keeping friends and allies, in obtaining the concord of the cities beyond the Rhine and of the Christian princes, in saluting the French, and in asking the private lands to remain faithful; and here, as to the matter of the cause, that it should be on the doors, that we should lose not only our former liberty, but also our primitive faith and the apostolical religion, which is none older, if we will be allied with the pagans.There are many things which you see more fitly, according to your sharp judgment, than I could show.

seg.output: I received your letters full of consolation on the 1st of December, from which I understand that your wisdom has succeeded in ensuring that the cities agree to keep their faith and avoid the calumnies of the pagans (as Myconius calls them).Indeed, our good fortune is foreshadowed and I do not know what it portends of the Lord's extraordinary mercy that Bernatium, Basileensium, and Scaphusianorum have offered their help.This seems to indicate, if I am not mistaken, that the solid piety which we have acknowledged for not so many years has established its roots more deeply than to be easily overwhelmed by the storms of evil.We also experience this in the faithful men of the common prefectures, who, although deprived of the freedom of doctrine, seem to be thrown down and even seized and oppressed by tyranny, yet in the midst of their affliction they stand upright in spirit and never cease to devise plans for supporting their ministers with their own money, so that we can plainly see that the word of the Lord, sown in a fruitful land, cannot fail to produce its fruit.What remains, therefore, the grace of the Lord seems to have achieved, namely, the constancy of the city of Tigurum, which is our metropolis in reality.Just consider what scandal would arise from there, if the city which is strong in men, order and authority, and which, as a pious mother, has provided the pure milk of the restored religion to the other Swiss cities, should fall from the grade of the received and so earnestly professed piety, when the conspiracies and storms of evil arise!For what was given in that military alliance for the time being does not pertain to the matter of faith, since everyone can see that it was patched together and forced, which the cunning of the opponents then demanded, and thus was done which is usually done in such kinds of deceit, that by examining the head of the alliance properly we can easily dissolve the deceit and avoid the calumny with the assertion of our own religion.I read with great pleasure your most circumspect plan; and since you ask what I think ought to be done, I answer that it does not appear to me to be advisable that the same method should be adopted in the beginning of the business, since there is hope that they will perceive that they cannot attain what they are attempting, especially since the people of our country may be affected in various ways and their minds alienated or excited towards new arts against us, as eager for novelties and neglectful of Swiss liberty.Moreover, I scarcely persuade myself that it will be as you kindly conjecture: that when we have renounced the alliances, they will easily keep the peace on any conditions; but rather I should fear that they would use what arts they could to alienate the fields from the cities in the pretext of retaining the old liberty and the name and glory of the Swiss, which they could easily accomplish if they were to make their own in some consumed and harassed fields, which are in the country, by setting fire to and vexing them; for you know how faithfully they kept to the Senate of Zurich lately, that is, in the last war, some of the country, who dared to withdraw themselves from their own affairs, not yet plundered or afflicted, and to make peace with the enemy, I know not, and to despise the magistrates.To which (to speak freely) we owe this so specious alliance, and we take it thankfully.Therefore, the first thing to be tried should be a more humane and more placable method, if perchance they should yield to humanity and grave meekness.If that cannot be accomplished, the next way according to equity will be to threaten them to dissolve the alliances; for to us these alliances, thus open to calumnies, are not alliances, but bonds of our liberty.Who knows whether they may not become more tractable at these threats?For they are not so dull as not to consider what evil would arise to them from our departure.If even this plan should not be able to avail, then one must do what you advise: namely, the alliances must be rescinded for the sake of retaining our liberty; but with much watchfulness and care must new friends and allies be sought, and concord must be sought with the cities beyond the Rhine and Christian princes, the French must be greeted and the private fields asked to remain faithful, and there must be consultation about the matter of the cause; namely, this must be at the door, that unless we will be allied to the pagans we shall lose not only our ancient liberty, but also our primitive faith and the apostolic religion, which is not more ancient than this.There are many things which you see better, according to your keen judgment, than I could show.This shall be the last and, as it is said, the sacred anchor.

et quandoquidem rogas, quid equidem agendum existimarem, respondeo: mihi non videri consultum, ut initio negotii ea ratio ineatur, cum quod spes sit futurum ut illi palam cernant, suos conatus assequi non posse, quod moliuntur, tum maxime, quod ad foederum solutionem vulgus nostrum varie affici et novis artibus adversum nos, ceu rerum novarum cupidis et libertatis Helveticae negligentibus, aut excitari aut alienari animis posset.Praeterea vix mihi persuadeo, id ita fore, quod tu quidem candide coniectas: quum foederibus nos renuntiarimus, pacem illos facile ullis condicionibus servaturos; quin magis id metuerem, quibus possent artibus daturos operam, ut praetextu veteris libertatis et Helvetici nominis atque gloriae retinendae agros passim ab urbibus alienarent, quod quidem bello coepto et alienis adductis auxiliis praesidiisque facile consequerentur, si pagis aliquot exustis et vexatis, qui sunt rure, passim suos facerent, qui iam nostri videntur.Scis enim, quam fidem praestiterint senatui Tigurino nuper, hoc est proximo bello, quidam ex agro, qui rebus suis nondum petitis aut adflictis secedere tamen et cum hoste, nescio et contempto magistratu, pacisci sunt ausi; quorum (ut libere dicam) perfidiae hocce tam speciosum foedus debemus et acceptum referimus.Proinde primum tentanda humaniora et placabilior ratio ineunda, si forte illi humanitati et gravi mansuetudini cedant locum.Ea si assequi nequit, qua ex aequitate est, proxima via erit minitandi, de solvendis scilicet foederibus: nobis enim foedera hoc modo calumniis patentia non foedera, sed vincula esse negat libertatis.Quis scit, an ad has minas fiant tractabiliores?Non enim sunt tam stupidi, quin expendere queant, quid mali illis paritura esset nostra discessio.Quodsi ne hoc quidem consilium posset proficere, tum in hoc esse, quod consulis: nempe nostrae libertatis retinendae gratia foedera illa rescindenda, scilicet interim multa vigilantia de novis ineundis et servandis amicis sociis, de urbium Transrhenanarum et principum Christianorum ambienda concordia, de Gallo salutando ac agris privatis hostiatim rogandis, in fidene mansuri, et inibi de caussae genere: nempe hoc esse in foribus, ut non libertatem modo pristinam, sed et fidem primaevam et religionem apostolicam, qua nulla antiquior est, amissuri simus, si foederati paganis esse velimus.Multa sunt, quae pro tuo acerrimo iudicio rectius vides, quam ego monstrare possem.Haec postrema erit et, quod dicitur, sacra ancora.Cura tantum, id quod sedulo facis, ut animis tuorum nihil decedat ad veritatem retinendam.
seg.output: On the 1st of December, I received your letter full of consolation, from which I understand that it was through your ingenuity that the cities agreed to remain faithful and to protect themselves from the false accusations of the pagans (as Myconius calls them).Indeed, it is a fortunate sign that Bernatius, the Baselisians and the Scaphusians have come to our aid, as it seems to me to indicate that the word of God has taken root more deeply than can be easily overturned by any storm of evil.The same thing we see in the faithful men of the common prefectures, who, although seemingly stripped of the freedom of teaching, oppressed by the tyranny and carried away, yet stand erect in the midst of their affliction and do not cease to devise plans for the maintenance of their ministers, so that we can plainly see that the word of the Lord, sown in a fruitful land, cannot fail to bring forth fruit.What remains, therefore, seems to be accomplished through the grace of the Lord, namely the constancy of the city of Zurich, which is in fact our metropolis.Consider what a scandal it would be if the city of yours, which is strong in men, order, and authority, and which, as a pious mother, has supplied the pure milk of restored religion to the rest of the Swiss cities, should be thrown from its rank of received and professed piety by the rising storm of conspiracies and evil arts!For that which was given in that military alliance for the time being does not concern the cause of religion, since everyone can see that it was forced and violent, and demanded by the craftiness of the enemies; and thus it was done, in accordance with the common practice in such craftiness, that by rightly inspecting the head of the alliance, we can now easily dissolve the deceit and avoid the calumny with the assertion of our religion.I have read with great pleasure your most circumspect plan; and since you ask what I think should be done, I answer that I do not think it prudent to begin the business in such a way, with the hope that they will see that they cannot accomplish what they undertake; especially since the people of our nation may be affected by new arts, eager for novelties and neglectful of Swiss freedom.Moreover, I can hardly believe what you candidly conjecture, that if we renounce the alliances, they will easily keep peace on any terms; rather, I would fear that by what means they would give attention to alienating the fields from the cities, under the pretext of the old freedom and of preserving the Swiss name and glory, which they could easily accomplish, if they were to make some fires and harassments in the country, which is already theirs.For you know what faith they kept to the senate of Zurich recently, that is, in the last war, some from the country, who, although not yet having lost or afflicted their own things, yet dared to secede and make peace with the enemy, and, I know not, to despise the magistracy; to whose perfidy (to speak freely) we owe this so splendid alliance, and to which we acceptably refer.Therefore, first of all, the more humane and placable way should be tried, if by any chance they yield to humanity and grave gentleness.If this cannot be done, then the next way, according to equity, will be to threaten, namely, to dissolve the alliances; for to us, these alliances, thus open to calumnies, are not alliances, but bonds of our freedom.Who knows, if by these threats they may be made tractable?For they are not so stupid as not to consider what evil would befall them from our departure.But if this plan also could not be of use, then that which you advise should be done: namely, for the sake of retaining our freedom, those alliances should be rescinded, and, meanwhile, much care should be taken in making and preserving new friends and allies, in seeking concord with the cities on the other side of the Rhine and with Christian princes, in saluting the Gallican, and in asking the private fields to stay faithful, and there, in the matter of cause: namely, that, if we wish to be in league with the pagans, we shall not only lose our former freedom, but also the primitive faith and the apostolic religion, which is none more ancient.There are many things which, through your most acute judgment, you see better than I could show.This last shall be, as it were, the sacred anchor.Take care only, as you do sedulously, that nothing be taken from the minds of your people with regard to retaining the truth.

seg.output: On the first of December I received your letters full of consolation, from which I understand that it was due to your prudence that cities agreed to remain faithful and to avert the calumnies of the pagans (as Myconius calls them).Certainly the auspicious Bernatius, of the Basel and Schaffhausen, gives us an indication of something extraordinary of the Lord's clemency.Indeed, if I am not mistaken, it shows that the solid piety and the same faith that has been recognized by us not for a long time, has taken its roots deeper, so as not to be easily overcome by any storms of evil.We experience the same in faithful men of the common prefectures, who, although they seem to be deprived of the freedom of doctrine, thrown and oppressed by tyranny, yet, in the midst of this affliction, they stand upright in spirit and do not cease to take counsel for the support of their ministers with their own resources, so that we may openly see that the word of the Lord, sown in a fruitful land, cannot fail to produce its fruit.What remains, it seems that they have obtained it by the grace of the Lord, namely the steadfastness of the city of Zurich, which is in fact our metropolis.Think what a scandal would arise from this, if the city of yours, which is so powerful in men, order and authority, and which, as a pious mother, has furnished to the other Swiss cities the pure milk of the restored religion, would fall from the degree of the received and so strongly professed piety, because of the conspiracies and mischievous arts!For what was granted to their fury for the time being in that military alliance, does not concern the consideration of that faith, since nobody does not see that it was put together and forced, which at that time was demanded by the craftiness of the adversaries, and thus was done, which often happens in this kind of fraud, that, by the same counsel, we can now easily dissolve the fraud and avoid the calumny, rightly inspecting the head of the alliance.I have read with great pleasure your most prudent counsel; and since you ask, what I would have thought to be done, I answer: it did not seem to me to be a good counsel to take this course at the beginning of the business, since there is hope that they will see that they can not attain what they undertake, especially when the people of ours may be affected in various ways and be excited or alienated in mind by the new arts, and be negligent of the Swiss liberty.Moreover, I hardly persuade myself that it will be so, as you candidly guess: that, when we shall have renounced the alliance, they will easily keep the peace at any conditions; rather I should fear that, by what arts they might give their help, they might detach the fields from the cities, under the pretence of the old liberty and of the Helvetic name and glory, which they might easily do, if they should set fire to and distress some countries, which are in the country, and make their partizans already ours.For you know how much fidelity has been given to the senate of Zurich lately, that is, in the last war, by some from the country, who, though their goods were not yet taken or afflicted, yet they dared to separate from us and to make peace with the enemy, I know not, and to despise the magistracy; to whose (if I may speak freely) perfidy we owe this stately alliance and accept it.Therefore, the first thing to be tried is a more humane and pacifying method, if perhaps they may yield to humanity and grave meekness.If this cannot be obtained, then the next way, according to equity, will be to threaten them to dissolve the alliance: for to us the alliance in this way open to calumnies, are not alliances, but bonds of liberty.Who knows, if they may be more tractable by these threats?For they are not so stupid, as not to consider what evil would be brought to them by our departure.If even this counsel should not be able to profit, then it is to be done which you counsel: namely, that we should rescind the alliance for the preservation of our liberty, and meantime with much watchfulness take care of the new friends and allies, of the cities on the Rhine and of the Christian princes, of saluting the French, and of asking the private fields to remain faithful; and there, of the nature of the cause: namely, that we shall not only lose the former liberty, but also the primitive faith and the apostolic religion, which is none more ancient, if we will to be allies to the pagans.There are many things, which you see more correctly, according to your keen judgment, than I could show.This last shall be, as it is said, the sacred anchor.Only be careful, as you do sedulously, that nothing be withdrawn from the minds of yours for retaining the truth.The day will come that will repair also to the age whatever loss the republic of yours has suffered from the former disaster.

seg.output:
I received your letters full of comfort on the 5th of December, from which I understand that it was your wisdom that caused the cities to agree to keep their faith and avert the calumnies of the pagans (as Myconius calls them). Truly, it was a good omen and I think I can perceive through Bernatius, the Baselians and Scaphusians, a certain sign of the Lord's extraordinary mercy. For it seems to me that it signifies that the word of the Lord has taken root deeply enough that it cannot easily be overwhelmed by any storm of evils. We also experience this in the faithful men governing the districts, who, although they seem to be deprived of the liberty of doctrine, lie in chains and oppressed by tyranny, yet their minds stand firm in the midst of affliction and they do not cease to devise ways of providing for the ministers with their own money, so that we can plainly see that the word of the Lord, sown in a fruitful land, cannot fail to yield its fruit. However, it seems that with the grace of the Lord they have already achieved the one thing that remains, namely the steadfastness of the city of Zurich, which is in fact our metropolis. Think of how much scandal would arise from it if the city of your people, which is strong in men and order and authority, and which, like a pious mother, has offered us that pure milk of the religion that has been lost, should fall from its place of the accepted and so firmly professed piety, in a storm of conspiracy and evil arts! For that which was conceded to the fury of their enemies at the time of that military alliance does not pertain to the question of that faith, since everyone can see that it was patched together and forced by the craftiness of our adversaries, and so it was done, which is usually the way in these plots, that by inspecting the head of the alliance rightly we can easily dissolve the fraud and avoid the calumny with the affirmation of our religion.
I read with great pleasure your most circumspect counsel; and since you ask me what I would think ought to be done, I answer that I do not think it wise to take the course in the beginning of the business that you so candidly conjecture, since there is hope that they will plainly see that they cannot attain that which they attempt, especially since the people of our country may be variously affected and their minds may be either excited or alienated with new arts against us, as those who are eager for new things and who neglect Swiss liberty. Besides, I can hardly persuade myself that it will be so, as you conjecture; for when we renounce the alliances, I would rather fear that they would use some arts by which they might, under the pretext of the ancient liberty and the glory of the Swiss name, alienate the fields from the towns in every place, which they could easily do if they made their own people, who are in the country, do it, after some towns had been burned and afflicted, which they seem to be already. For you know how faithful those of the country were recently, that is, in the last war, to the senate of Zurich; to whom (to speak freely) we owe this specious alliance and accept it in return.
Therefore, the first thing to be attempted is a more humane and placable course of action, if by any chance they should yield to humanity and grave gentleness. If this cannot be attained, then the next way is to threaten them with the dissolution of the alliances; for to us these alliances, thus liable to calumnies, are not alliances, but bonds of our liberty. Who knows but that they may be tractable to these threats? For they are not so stupid as not to consider what evil would come to them by our departure. But if this counsel also should not be of any avail, then we must do what you advise: namely, that we rescind the alliances for the sake of retaining our liberty; provided we take great care in making and keeping new friends and allies, in gaining the concord of the towns beyond the Rhine and Christian princes, in saluting the French and begging the private fields one by one to remain faithful, and also in the kind of cause: namely, that we shall lose not only our ancient liberty, but also the primitive faith and apostolic religion, which is the most ancient of all, if we will be allies of the pagans. There are many things which you see more correctly, according to your acute judgment, than I could show. This will be the last and, as it is said, sacred anchor. Take care only, as you do sedulously, that nothing of truth should be wanting in the minds of your people. The day will come which will even restore to the age whatever loss and damage the republic of your people has suffered. Our God is rich and is used to blessing those who love Him even with kingdoms.

Kalendas Decembres literas tuas plenas consolationis accepi, ex quibus intelligo, partum esse vestra solertia, ut in fide retinenda et avertendis paganorum (sic eos Myconius vocat) calumniis urbes consentirent.Profecto auspicatum est et nescio quid eximiae miserationis dominicae nobis adumbrat Bernatium, Basileensium, Scaphusianorum auxilium.Significat enim, nisi fallor, solidam pietatem et ipsam non ita multis annis nobis agnitam fidem, quae verbo illius nititur, suas radices altius egisse, quam ut ullis malorum procellis facile queat obrui.Idem in hominibus fidelibus communium praefecturarum experimur, qui, quanquam doctrinae libertate spoliati iacere atque adeo rapti et oppressi tyrannide videantur, in media tamen afflictione sic stant erecti animis nec desinunt de ministris suo aere alendis inire consilia, ut palam videre habeamus, verbum domini in terram frugiferam seminatum non posse non reddere suum fructum.Quod restat igitur, hoc ipsum gratia domini videntur assecuti, nempe constantiam Tigurinae urbis, quae re ipsa nostra metropolis est.Cogita vero, quantum scandali inde nasceretur, si, quae viris, quae ordine, quae auctoritate valet civitas vestra, quaeque ceu pia mater reliquis urbibus Helveticis lac illud purum defecatae religionis praebuit, obortis conspirationum et malarum artium procellis de gradu caderet receptae et tanta cum asseveratione professae pietatis!Nam quod illorum furori pro tempore est in militari illo foedere datum, non attinet ad illius fidei rationem, quum nemo non videat, consuta violentaque esse, quae tunc adversariorum versutia postulavit, atque adeo factum, quod plerumque in hoc doli genere usu venit, ut, quo illi consilia sua in militia confirmare et nostra infirmare tentarunt, eodem consilio iam nunc nos, capite illo foederis recte inspecto, diluere dolum et calumniam declinare cum assertione religionis nostrae facile possimus.Legi vero magna cum voluptate consilium tuum circumspectissimum; et quandoquidem rogas, quid equidem agendum existimarem, respondeo: mihi non videri consultum, ut initio negotii ea ratio ineatur, cum quod spes sit futurum ut illi palam cernant, suos conatus assequi non posse, quod moliuntur, tum maxime, quod ad foederum solutionem vulgus nostrum varie affici et novis artibus adversum nos, ceu rerum novarum cupidis et libertatis Helveticae negligentibus, aut excitari aut alienari animis posset.Praeterea vix mihi persuadeo, id ita fore, quod tu quidem candide coniectas: quum foederibus nos renuntiarimus, pacem illos facile ullis condicionibus servaturos; quin magis id metuerem, quibus possent artibus daturos operam, ut praetextu veteris libertatis et Helvetici nominis atque gloriae retinendae agros passim ab urbibus alienarent, quod quidem bello coepto et alienis adductis auxiliis praesidiisque facile consequerentur, si pagis aliquot exustis et vexatis, qui sunt rure, passim suos facerent, qui iam nostri videntur.Scis enim, quam fidem praestiterint senatui Tigurino nuper, hoc est proximo bello, quidam ex agro, qui rebus suis nondum petitis aut adflictis secedere tamen et cum hoste, nescio et contempto magistratu, pacisci sunt ausi; quorum (ut libere dicam) perfidiae hocce tam speciosum foedus debemus et acceptum referimus.Proinde primum tentanda humaniora et placabilior ratio ineunda, si forte illi humanitati et gravi mansuetudini cedant locum.Ea si assequi nequit, qua ex aequitate est, proxima via erit minitandi, de solvendis scilicet foederibus: nobis enim foedera hoc modo calumniis patentia non foedera, sed vincula esse negat libertatis.Quis scit, an ad has minas fiant tractabiliores?Non enim sunt tam stupidi, quin expendere queant, quid mali illis paritura esset nostra discessio.Quodsi ne hoc quidem consilium posset proficere, tum in hoc esse, quod consulis: nempe nostrae libertatis retinendae gratia foedera illa rescindenda, scilicet interim multa vigilantia de novis ineundis et servandis amicis sociis, de urbium Transrhenanarum et principum Christianorum ambienda concordia, de Gallo salutando ac agris privatis hostiatim rogandis, in fidene mansuri, et inibi de caussae genere: nempe hoc esse in foribus, ut non libertatem modo pristinam, sed et fidem primaevam et religionem apostolicam, qua nulla antiquior est, amissuri simus, si foederati paganis esse velimus.Multa sunt, quae pro tuo acerrimo iudicio rectius vides, quam ego monstrare possem.Haec postrema erit et, quod dicitur, sacra ancora.Cura tantum, id quod sedulo facis, ut animis tuorum nihil decedat ad veritatem retinendam.Veniet dies, quae resarciet etiam saeculo, quicquid damni clade superiori respublica vestra pertulit.Dives est deus noster et se diligentes beare etiam regnis assuevit.De Caesare securi estote.
seg.output: I received your letter on the 1st of December full of consolation, from which I understand that it was due to your wisdom that the cities agreed to maintain their faith and repel the calumnies of the pagans (as Myconius calls them).Indeed, Bernatius, the Baselians and the Scaphusians have auspiciously foreshadowed something of the extraordinary mercy of the Lord.For, if I am not mistaken, it indicates that they have deepened the roots of their solid piety, which is based on His word, more deeply than to be easily overwhelmed by any storms of evil.We experience the same in the faithful men of the common provinces, who, although they seem to be deprived of the freedom of teaching, thrown down and oppressed by tyranny, yet stand so erect in their spirit in the midst of their afflictions and do not cease to devise means for maintaining their ministers with their own money, so that we may openly see that the word of the Lord, when sown in a fertile land, cannot not produce its fruit.Therefore, it seems that they have achieved this by the grace of the Lord, namely, the constancy of the city of Zurich, which is our metropolis in fact.Think how much scandal would arise from there, if the city of your own, which is powerful in men, order and authority and which, as a pious mother, has provided the pure milk of the corrupted religion to the other Swiss cities, would fall from the degree of the received and so earnestly professed piety when the storms of conspiracy and evil arts arise!For what was given in that military league for the time being does not concern the reason of that faith, since everyone can see that it was made by coercion and violence, which the craft of the adversaries then asked for, and so it was done, which usually happens in this kind of fraud, so that, by rightly inspecting the head of the league, we can easily dissolve the fraud and avoid the calumny with the assertion of our own religion.I read with great pleasure your most circumspect advice; and since you ask what I think should be done, I answer that I do not think it is advisable to take this approach at the beginning of the business, since there is hope that they will see that they cannot achieve what they are trying to do, especially since the people of our country can be affected in different ways and, being eager for new things and being negligent of the Swiss freedom, can be aroused or alienated in their minds.Moreover, I hardly persuade myself that it will be as you candidly conjecture, that if we renounce the league, they will easily keep the peace under any conditions; rather, I would fear that they would use it in such a way that, under the pretext of the old freedom and keeping the Swiss name and glory, they could alienate the fields from the cities everywhere, which they could easily do if they set their own people in the farms, who are already ours, when they have started the war and brought foreign help and garrisons.For you know how faithful some of the farmers of the country were to the senate of Zurich recently, that is, in the last war, who dared to secede from their things, not yet seized or afflicted, and to make peace with the enemy, I do not know, and despised the magistrate.For this so beautiful league we owe and accept their treachery (to speak freely).Therefore, the more humane and more placable approach should be tried first, if by chance they give way to humanity and serious gentleness.If this cannot be achieved, the next way will be to threaten to dissolve the league; for to us the leagues thus open to calumnies are not leagues but bonds of freedom.Who knows if they will become more tractable by these threats?For they are not so stupid as not to be able to consider what evil would be caused by our departure.If even this advice could not be profitable, then the thing you advise should be done, namely, that the leagues should be rescinded for the sake of preserving our freedom; namely, to take care in the meantime to enter into and keep new friends and associates, to seek the agreement of the transrhenane cities and Christian princes, to salute the Gauls and to ask the private fields one by one to be faithful, and there to settle the cause: namely, that we will not only lose our ancient freedom, but also the primitive faith and apostolic religion, which is none older, if we want to be federated with the pagans.There are many things that you see better for your sharp judgment than I could show.This last one will be, as it is said, the sacred anchor.Take care, as you do diligently, that nothing of your truth is lost.The day will come that will even restore to the century whatever damage your state has suffered from the previous disaster.Our God is rich and He is used to blessing those who diligently seek Him.Be assured of the Caesar.

seg.output:
I received your letters full of consolation on the first of December, from which I understand that your wisdom has been able to persuade the cities to keep their faith and resist the calumnies of the pagans (as Myconius calls them). Certainly, your auspice is blessed, and I do not know what divine mercy is suggesting to us through the help of Bernatius, Basileensium and Scaphusianorum. He seems to me, unless I am wrong, that the solid piety and faith that we have recognised for not too many years now has dug its roots much deeper than to be easily buried by any storms of evil. We also experience this in the faithful people of our common prefectures, who, although they seem to be robbed of their freedom of teaching, thrown down and oppressed by tyranny, still stand up with spirit in the middle of the affliction and do not stop making plans to feed their ministers with their own resources, so that we can clearly see that the word of the Lord sown in the fertile land cannot fail to bring its fruit.
What remains, then, seems to have been achieved by the grace of the Lord, namely the constancy of the city of Zurich, which is our metropolis in itself. Just think how much scandal would arise if the city, which is powerful in men, order and authority, and which, like a pious mother, has provided that pure milk of restored religion to the other Swiss cities, were to fall from its accepted and professed piety with the rising of conspiracies and storms of evil arts! For what was conceded in that military pact for the time being does not affect the reason of the faith, since everyone can see that it was patched up and enforced by the cunning of our opponents, and so it was done as is usually done in this kind of fraud, that with right inspection of that head of the pact we can easily dissolve the fraud and avoid the calumny with the assertion of our religion.
I read with great pleasure your most circumspect plan, and since you ask what I would think the best course of action to be, I answer that I do not think it advisable to start with that course of action, since there is a hope that they will see that they cannot achieve what they are trying to do, especially since the people of our country could be affected in various ways and have their minds either stirred up or alienated from the new arts and the negligence of Swiss liberty. Moreover, I hardly think that it will be as you candidly conjecture, that if we renounce the pacts they will easily keep the peace under any conditions; rather, I would fear that they would use all kinds of arts to alienate the lands from the cities under the pretext of retaining the old freedom and the name and glory of Switzerland, which they would easily be able to do if a few fields were set on fire and harassed, which is already the case in the countryside. You know how faithful certain people from the countryside were to the Senate of Zurich in the recent, that is, the last war, who dared to secede and make peace with the enemy, I do not know, and to despise the magistracy; to whom (to speak freely) we owe this so honourable pact and accept it with thanks.
Therefore, the first thing to be tried should be a kinder and more placable approach, in case they yield to humanity and serious gentleness. If this cannot be achieved, then the next step would be to threaten them to dissolve the pacts, since for us, these pacts open to calumnies are not pacts but bonds of liberty. Who knows, they may be more tractable to these threats? For they are not so stupid as not to be able to see what harm our departure would bring them. If even this plan could not be successful, then we should do what you suggest: namely, we should rescind the pacts in order to retain our freedom, but at the same time take great care in making and keeping new friends and allies, in seeking the concord of the cities across the Rhine and Christian princes, in greeting the Gaul and in asking the private fields to remain faithful, and also in other matters of cause: namely, that it is already at the door that if we want to be allied with the pagans, we will not only lose our original freedom, but also the original faith and apostolic religion, which is the most ancient of all. There are many things that you see more rightly according to your sharp judgment than I could show. This will be the last and, as they say, the sacred anchor. Just take care, as you do diligently, that there is nothing lacking in the minds of your people to preserve the truth. The day will come that will even restore to the age whatever damage was caused to your republic by the previous disaster. Our God is rich and He usually blesses those who are devoted to Him, even with kingdoms. Be at ease about the Caesar. He has dismissed a great number of German soldiers, and they do not think that their plan is anything other than to embark on the waters in the spring and return to Spain.

I received your letters full of consolation in December of the Calends, from which I understand that it was your wisdom that caused the cities to agree in keeping their faith and warding off the slanders of the pagans - as Myconius calls them. Indeed it was a fortunate omen, and I do not know what sort of extraordinary divine mercy it is that Bernard, the Baselians, and the Scaphusians are foreshadowing. For it seems, unless I am mistaken, that their solid piety and the faith which has been acknowledged by us for not many years has taken its roots deeper than to be easily buried under any storms of evil. The same thing we experience in the faithful men of the common governments, who, although they appear to be bereft of the freedom of doctrine, thrown down and oppressed by tyranny, yet in the midst of their affliction stand up so stoutly in spirit and do not cease to devise means for the support of their ministers, that we may clearly behold that the word of the Lord, sown in a fruitful ground, cannot but bring forth fruit. What then remains is, that they seem to have attained it by the grace of the Lord, namely, the constancy of the city of Zurich, which is in truth our metropolis. Think, I pray you, what scandal would arise from hence, if that city, which is strong in men, order, and authority, and which, as a pious mother, has furnished that pure milk of the decayed religion to the other Swiss cities, should, by the rising of conspiracies and storms of wicked arts, fall from the degree of the received and so openly professed piety. For that which was in that military league granted to them for the time being, does not belong to the account of that faith, since nobody does not see that it was knit together and forced, which then the craft of the adversaries required, and that it was done, which is commonly used in this kind of guile, that by the same counsel, by rightly inspecting the head of that league, we may easily dissolve the fraud and decline the slander with the assertion of our own religion.
But I read with great pleasure your most circumspect counsel, and since you ask what I think ought to be done, I answer that it seems not to be prudent to take this course at the beginning of the business, since there is hope that they may plainly see that they cannot accomplish what they undertake, especially since the people of our country might be differently affected and either excited or alienated in mind by new arts against us, as being desirous of novelties and neglectful of the Swiss liberty. Moreover, I hardly persuade myself that it will be so, as you candidly conjecture, when we shall have renounced the leagues, that they will easily keep peace upon any conditions. Nay, rather, I should fear, by what arts they would give their assistance, that, under colour of their ancient liberty and of the name and glory of the Swiss, they might alienate the fields from the cities, which they could easily do when they had begun the war and brought in foreign aid and defences, if they should set fire to a few of the country villages and vex them, which already seem to be ours.

seg.output: I truly admire your most prudent advice, and since you ask me what I think should be done, I think it would not be wise to start the affair with a strategy where it is expected that they will see they cannot attain what they are attempting, especially since our people could be affected in various ways and grow excited with the prospect of new things or become careless about Swiss liberty. To that perfidy of theirs we owe, if I may say so freely, this splendid treaty, which we accept. Therefore, the first step should be to try a more humane and placating way, should they be open to humanity and serious gentleness. If that cannot be achieved, then the next step, in fairness, should be threats to dissolve the treaties. For us, these treaties, open to calumnies, are not treaties but chains of denied liberty. Who knows if they will become more tractable by these threats? For they are not so dull that they cannot figure out what harm our leaving would bring them. If this plan also fails, then it is necessary to do as you suggest, that is, for the sake of preserving our liberty, to annul the treaties, being vigilant to make new ones and keep them, to reconcile with the Rhine cities and Christian princes, to salute the French and ask the private lands to remain loyal, and ultimately, to consider that if we want to be in league with pagans, we will not only lose our former liberty, but also our ancient faith and the Apostolic religion, which is the oldest of all.
