seg.output: I fully agree with your very wise plan, and since you ask what I think should be done, I do not think it would be wise to start off the business by going down a route that would cause them to clearly see their attempts would not bear fruit, especially because our people could be affected in various ways with a new craft and be either excited or alienated by the negligence or freedom of Switzerland. Furthermore, I find it hard to believe it will be as you have kindly suggested, that they would easily keep the peace under any conditions if we reject the treaties. Rather, I fear they would use all kinds of devices to separate the land from the cities in the name of keeping their old freedom and the glory of Switzerland, which could easily be done if they start a war with the help of foreigners, and make their people in the country, who already appear to be our own, suffer by burning and damaging some of the provinces. For you know how they have recently kept their promise to the Senate of Zurich, that is, some of the people in the country, even before they could take or damage their own possessions, had the audacity to leave and make peace with the enemy and the despised magistrate. To which, I must say, we owe this splendid treaty and accept it. Therefore, the first thing to do is to try kinder and more conciliatory approaches, in case they would give in to humanity and a serious gentleness. If that cannot be achieved, then, as is fair, the next step would be to threaten them about the dissolution of the treaties. For us, these treaties are not an alliance of denied freedom, but an open calumny. Who knows, if they would be more tractable to these threats? For they are not so stupid that they can't understand what harm would come to them from our departure. If even this plan wouldn't work, then it must be done as you suggest, that is, for the sake of keeping our freedom, we must renounce these treaties. In the meantime, we must be very vigilant in making and keeping new friends, in making an agreement with the Transrhenish cities and Christian princes, in greeting the Gaul and asking for fields to be taken as hostages, and to stay in faith, and there decide on the matter, that is, if we want to be associated with the pagans, we would not only lose our former freedom, but also the primeval faith and the apostolic religion, which is the oldest of all. There are many things you see more accurately than I could show, due to your sharp judgement.

seg.output: I fully approve of your most prudent plan, and since you ask me what I think ought to be done, I answer that it does not seem advisable to begin the business by adopting a course which holds out a hope that they will clearly perceive their efforts to be ineffectual in attaining what they attempt; especially as our people might be affected in various ways by the dissolution of the alliance, and be disposed either to be carried away by the novelty of things, or to be regardless of Swiss liberty. Moreover, I can scarcely persuade myself that what you conjure up with candour will take place, viz. that should we renounce the alliance, they will easily keep the peace on any conditions. Nay, rather, I should fear that they would use every art to alienate from us the lands in general, from the cities; under the pretext of preserving the ancient liberty, and the fame and glory of Switzerland, which they might easily accomplish, if they set on fire and ravaged some of the districts, which are in the country, and raised bands of our own people, who already appear disposed to do so. You know with what fidelity they recently kept their engagement to the Senate of Zurich, that is, during the late war, some of the people in the country, before their property was attacked or injured, yet ventured to desert us, and to enter into a treaty with the enemy, and that in contempt of the magistracy. To this perfidy of theirs we owe, as I may freely say, the present handsome alliance, and acknowledge it as accepted. Therefore the first thing to be attempted must be some milder and more placable measures, if possibly they will yield to humanity and gravity. If this cannot be effected, then the next course, according to equity, must be to threaten to dissolve the alliance; for to us the alliance would be no better than a chain of slavery, if it were liable to calumny. Who knows but that they may be rendered more tractable by this menace? For they are not so stupid as not to consider what mischief would ensue to them from our secession. If this also should not succeed, it will then come to what you propose, viz. that for the sake of preserving our liberty we should rescind the alliance, but in the mean time take great care to make and preserve friends and allies, to endeavour to procure harmony between the cities on the other side of the Rhine, and the Christian princes, to approach the French in a friendly manner, and to demand the lands in the country as private property, engaging to remain faithful; and to have one point before our eyes, viz. that we should lose not only our ancient liberty, but the primitive faith, and the apostolical religion, which is of all others the most ancient, if we would be allied to the Pagans. There are many things which, according to your excellent judgment, you see better than I could point out. This shall be the last resource, and, as it is called, the sacred anchor.

I received your letters the fifth of the calends of December full of consolation, from which I understand that your industry has brought it about that the cities consent to remain in the faith and to avert the calumnies of the pagans (so Myconius calls them). Truly it is a happy omen and something of an extraordinary divine compassion is shadowed to us by Bernatius, the Basle, and the Schaffhausen aid. On the first of December, I received your letter full of consolation, from which I understand that your wisdom has made it so that the cities have agreed to keep their faith and to avert the accusations of the pagans (that is how Myconius calls them). It appears to have been auspiciously decided and I don't know what the Lord's exceptional mercy has hinted to us through the help of the Bernatians, the Basileensians, and the Scaphusians. It seems to signify, if I am not mistaken, that a strong piety and faith, which we have only recently recognized, has spread its roots deeper than can be easily uprooted by any storms of evils. We experience the same in faithful people of the common jurisdictions, who, although they are deprived of freedom of doctrine and seem to be lying, seized, and oppressed by tyranny, still have such upright spirits in the midst of affliction and do not stop to take counsel to nourish their ministers by their own means, so that we can clearly see that the word of the Lord, sown in a fertile ground, can not fail to yield its fruit.
Therefore, what remains appears to have been achieved by the grace of the Lord, namely the steadfastness of the city of Zurich, which is our capital in reality. Imagine, how much scandal would arise from it, if the city that is powerful due to its men, order, and authority, and which, like a pious mother, has provided the pure milk of the restored religion to the other Swiss cities, should fall from the degree of the received and so earnestly professed piety when storms of conspiracies and evil arts arise!

seg.output: On December 1st I received your letter full of consolation, from which I understand that your wisdom has caused the cities to agree to keep their faith and to repel the calumnies of the pagans (as Myconius calls them). Indeed, it seems to be an auspicious sign, and I don't know what to make of it, that Bernatius, Basileensium and Scaphusianorum have come to our aid with such an extraordinary mercy. For it indicates, if I'm not mistaken, that the faith that was not so long ago accepted by us has its roots deep enough that it cannot easily be overwhelmed by any storms of evil. The same we experience in the faithful men of the common prefectures, who, although deprived of freedom of doctrine, lay and are even seized and oppressed by tyranny, nevertheless stand erect in the middle of affliction with their minds and they do not cease to take counsel on how to sustain their ministers with their own money, so that we may clearly see that the word of the Lord, sown in a fruitful land, cannot fail to bring forth its fruit. What remains, therefore, seems to have been achieved by the grace of the Lord, namely the constancy of the city of Zurich, which is in fact our metropolis. Think of how much scandal would arise if the city of your vigour, order and authority, which as a pious mother gave the pure milk of the lost religion to the other Swiss cities, would fall from its degree of received and so earnestly professed piety when storms of conspiracies and wicked arts arise! For what was given in that military treaty for the time being to their fury does not relate to the reason of that faith, since everyone can see that it was sewn and violent, which was then demanded by the subtlety of the adversaries, and therefore it was done in a way that is usually used in this kind of fraud, so that, by the same counsel, we can now easily dissolve the fraud and avoid the calumny with the assertion of our religion, by correctly examining that head of the treaty. I also read with great pleasure your most vigilant advice, and since you ask what I would think was to be done, I answer: I do not think it wise to take such a course of action in the beginning of the business, since there is hope that they will clearly see that they cannot achieve what they are trying to do, especially since the people of our nation could be moved or alienated in their minds by various means and by a desire for new things and a neglect for Swiss freedom.

seg.output: I received your letter on the first of December full of consolation, from which I understand that it was by your wisdom that the cities agreed to remain faithful and to repel the calumnies of the pagans (as Myconius calls them). Certainly it was auspicious and something of an extraordinary mercy from the Lord is foreshadowed to us by the help of the Bernese, the Baselers and the Schaffhausers. For it shows, if I do not err, that the solid piety and faith recognised by us not many years ago has sunk its roots deeper than to be easily overwhelmed by any storm of evils. The same we experience in the faithful men of the common magistracies, who, although they appear deprived of the freedom of teaching, plundered, carried away and oppressed by tyranny, yet in the midst of their affliction stand erect in spirit and do not cease to take counsel for maintaining their own ministers at their own charges, so that we plainly see that the word of the Lord, sown into a fruitful land, cannot but bring forth fruit. What remains therefore, seems to have been achieved by the grace of the Lord, namely, the steadfastness of the city of Zurich, which is in fact our metropolis. Consider, how much scandal would arise from thence, if that city, which is strong in men, order and authority, and which as a pious mother has supplied to the other Swiss cities the pure milk of reformed religion, should fall from the degree of the received and so firmly professed piety, by the rising of conspiracies and storms of wicked arts! For what was granted in that military alliance for the time being does not refer to the reason of that faith, since everyone sees that it was patched up and forced, which then the craft of the adversaries demanded, and so done, which is usually done in this kind of deceit, that, by the same counsel which they have tried to confirm their own designs and to weaken ours, we may now, the head of the alliance being rightly inspected, easily dissolve the deceit and repel the calumny with the assertion of our own religion. But I read with great pleasure your most circumspect advice; and since you ask what I should think to be done, I answer: I do not think it to be prudent to take this course at the beginning of the business, that they should see that their endeavours cannot be obtained, especially because the people of our nation might be affected in various ways, and either excited or alienated from us by new arts, as being desirous of novelty and negligent of the Swiss liberty. Moreover, I hardly persuade myself that it will be so, as you candidly conjecture, that when we shall have renounced the alliances, they will easily keep peace upon any conditions; but rather I should fear, by what arts they might endeavor to alienate the fields from the cities in the name of the ancient liberty and of the glory of the Swiss name to be preserved, which they might easily effect, if they should make their own people, who are in the country, by burning and vexing a few districts, and whom now we seem to have. For you know how faithful some of the country people were lately, that is, in the late war, to the senate of Zurich, who, not having yet had their own goods plundered or afflicted, were yet bold to secede from us and to make peace with the enemy, I know not how, and to contemn the magistracy; to whose perfidy we owe this so specious alliance, and acknowledge it thankfully.

For you know how faithfully those of the country gave their obedience to the senate of Zurich in the late war; to wit, that some of them, without waiting to be oppressed in their goods, have presumed, I know not with what contempt of magistracy, to make peace with the enemy. Wherefore, the gentler and more pacific way should first be tried, if peradventure they will yield to humanity and grave meekness.

Idem in hominibus fidelibus communium praefecturarum experimur, qui, quanquam doctrinae libertate spoliati iacere atque adeo rapti et oppressi tyrannide videantur, in media tamen afflictione sic stant erecti animis nec desinunt de ministris suo aere alendis inire consilia, ut palam videre habeamus, verbum domini in terram frugiferam seminatum non posse non reddere suum fructum. Quod restat igitur, hoc ipsum gratia domini videntur assecuti, nempe constantiam Tigurinae urbis, quae re ipsa nostra metropolis est. Cogita vero, quantum scandali inde nasceretur, si, quae viris, quae ordine, quae auctoritate valet civitas vestra, quaeque ceu pia mater reliquis urbibus Helveticis lac illud purum defecatae religionis praebuit, obortis conspirationum et malarum artium procellis de gradu caderet receptae et tanta cum asseveratione professae pietatis! Nam quod illorum furori pro tempore est in militari illo foedere datum, non attinet ad illius fidei rationem, quum nemo non videat, consuta violentaque esse, quae tunc adversariorum versutia postulavit, atque adeo factum, quod plerumque in hoc doli genere usu venit, ut, quo illi consilia sua in militia confirmare et nostra infirmare tentarunt, eodem consilio iam nunc nos, capite illo foederis recte inspecto, diluere dolum et calumniam declinare cum assertione religionis nostrae facile possimus. Legi vero magna cum voluptate consilium tuum circumspectissimum; et quandoquidem rogas, quid equidem agendum existimarem, respondeo: mihi non videri consultum, ut initio negotii ea ratio ineatur, cum quod spes sit futurum ut illi palam cernant, suos conatus assequi non posse, quod moliuntur, tum maxime, quod ad foederum solutionem vulgus nostrum varie affici et novis artibus adversum nos, ceu rerum novarum cupidis et libertatis Helveticae negligentibus, aut excitari aut alienari animis posset. Praeterea vix mihi persuadeo, id ita fore, quod tu quidem candide coniectas: quum foederibus nos renuntiarimus, pacem illos facile ullis condicionibus servaturos; quin magis id metuerem, quibus possent artibus daturos operam, ut praetextu veteris libertatis et Helvetici nominis atque gloriae retinendae agros passim ab urbibus alienarent, quod quidem bello coepto et alienis adductis auxiliis praesidiisque facile consequerentur, si pagis aliquot exustis et vexatis, qui sunt rure, passim suos facerent, qui iam nostri videntur. Ea si assequi nequit, qua ex aequitate est, proxima via erit minitandi, de solvendis scilicet foederibus: nobis enim foedera hoc modo calumniis patentia non foedera, sed vincula esse negat libertatis.
seg.output: I received your letters on the first of December full of consolation, from which I understand that it was due to your skill that the cities agreed to remain true to their faith and to ward off the false accusations of the pagans (as Myconius calls them). Certainly Bernatius of Basel and the Scaphusians have been auspiciously chosen, and I believe they offer us a hint of some extraordinary divine mercy. For it appears to me that their solid piety, which has been acknowledged by us only for a few years, has taken its roots deeper than to be easily buried by any storm of evils. We experience the same in the faithful men of the common prefectures, who, although they seem to be deprived of the liberty of doctrine and thrown down and oppressed by tyranny, still stand with such erect minds in the midst of their affliction and do not cease to devise means for maintaining their ministers with their own money, so that we may clearly see that the word of the Lord, when sown in a fruitful land, cannot fail to bear fruit. What remains, therefore, seems to have been attained by the grace of the Lord, namely, the constancy of the city of Zurich, which is in fact our metropolis. Think how great a scandal would arise from it, if the city of yours, which is strong in men, order and authority, and which, as a pious mother, has offered to the other Swiss cities the pure milk of the decayed religion, should fall from its degree of received and so strongly professed piety, by the rising of conspiracies and storms of evil arts! For that which was given in that military alliance, for the time, does not pertain to the reason of that faith, since it is evident that it was woven and forced, and that which the subtlety of our adversaries then required; and thus it was done, which usually happens in this species of fraud, that, by which they endeavored to confirm their counsels in war, and to weaken ours, we can now, upon a right inspection of that head of the alliance, easily dissolve the fraud and avoid the false accusation with the assertion of our own religion. I read with great pleasure your very circumspect advice, and since you ask what I should think to be done, I answer: It does not seem to me to be prudent to take at the beginning of the business such a course, as there is hope that they will soon see that they cannot effect what they aim at, especially because the people of our country might, by the variety of their affections, be excited or alienated in mind by new arts, and by negligence to the liberty of the Swiss. Moreover, I hardly persuade myself that it will be as you candidly conjecture, that, when we have renounced the alliances, they will easily be kept in peace upon any conditions; but I rather fear that they may use such arts, as may alienate the lands from the cities, under pretext of the old liberty, and to retain the name and glory of the Swiss, which, upon the beginning of a war, and the assistance of foreigners, they may easily accomplish, if they should raise in the country some of their own, who already seem to be ours. For you know how they performed to the senate of Zurich lately, that is, in the last war, some of the country, who, without their goods being yet taken or afflicted, yet had the boldness to depart and to make peace with the enemy, and, I know not how, to contemn the magistrates; to whose perfidy we owe this so specious alliance, and acknowledge it thankfully. Wherefore, the first thing to be attempted will be a more humane and placable course, if peradventure they shall give place to humanity and grave meekness. And if this cannot be obtained, then the next way, according to equity, will be to threaten them with the dissolution of the alliances; for to us the alliances, thus open to calumnies, are not alliances, but bonds of slavery.

seg.output: I received your letters on the 1st of December full of consolation, from which I understand that it was your wisdom that made the cities agree to keep their faith and to ward off the calumnies of the pagans (as Myconius calls them). Certainly, Bernatius, the Baselians and the Scaphusians have promised a very auspicious and something of an extraordinary divine pity. For, as I suppose, it signifies that the solid piety and the faith which we have acknowledged not so many years ago has taken its roots deeper, so that it cannot be covered by any storms of evils. We experience the same in the faithful men of the common prefectures, who, although they seem to suffer and be oppressed by tyranny, deprived of liberty of doctrine, yet remain standing in the middle of affliction and do not cease to take counsel for the maintenance of their ministers, so that we may openly see that the word of the Lord, sown on a fruitful land, cannot but bring forth fruit. What remains, therefore, is that, by the grace of the Lord, they have obtained the constancy of the city of Zurich, which is, in effect, our metropolis. Consider, therefore, what scandal would arise from hence, if the city of yours, which is fortified by men, order and authority, and which, like a pious mother, has given that pure milk of the recovered religion to the other Swiss cities, should, by the rising of conspiracies and storms of evil arts, fall from the degree of the received and so professed piety with so much assurance! For that which was given to their fury for the time in that military league does not concern the right of that faith, since no one does not see that it was made up of violent and contrived things, which the artifice of the adversaries then required, and therefore was done, which often comes in this kind of craft, that, by the same counsel, now we, rightly inspecting the head of the league, can easily dissolve the cheat and avoid the calumny with the affirmation of our own religion. I have read with great satisfaction your most circumspect counsel; and since you ask what I think to be done, I answer: it does not seem to me to be prudent to take the first course of the business, when there is hope that they may plainly see that they cannot effect what they intend, especially because the people of ours might be affected in various ways and their minds alienated or excited to new arts against us, as being greedy of new things and negligent of the Swiss liberty. Moreover, I hardly persuade myself that it will be as you candidly conjecture, when we shall have renounced the leagues, that they will easily keep peace upon any terms; rather I should fear, by what arts they would apply themselves, that, under color of the old liberty and of the name and glory of the Swiss to be retained, they might alienate the lands in general from the cities; which they could easily do, when the war was begun and foreign helps and guards brought in, if they should make their own people in the country, who are already ours, scattered and vexed. For you know how faithful they were lately to the senate of Zurich, that is, in the last war, some of the country, who, their affairs not yet being demanded or afflicted, yet had the confidence to withdraw themselves and to treat of peace with the enemy, and, as I may freely speak, to the contempt of the magistrate; to whose perfidy we owe this so specious league and accept it. Therefore, the more gentle and pacifying way must first be tried, if haply they will yield to gentleness and grave mildness. If this cannot be obtained, then the next way must be to threaten of the leagues to be dissolved, for the leagues so calumniated are not leagues, but bonds of our liberty. Who knows but that they may be rendered tractable by these menaces? For they are not so stupid, but that they may consider what mischief would follow upon our departure. And if this counsel also could not take effect, then this must be done which you advise: namely, that, for the retaining of our liberty, the said leagues must be rescinded, provided withal that great care be taken of new leagues to be taken and kept, of the concord of the cities beyond the Rhine and of the Christian princes to be sought, of the greeting of the Gaul and of the private fields to be asked, to remain in fidelity, and thereupon, of the manner of the cause, that is, that we shall lose not only our former liberty, but also the first and apostolic religion, which none is more ancient than, if we should be leagued with the pagans.

seg.output: I received your letters on the first of December full of consolation, from which I understand that it was through your wisdom that the cities agreed to remain faithful and to repel the calumnies of the pagans (as Myconius calls them). Indeed, it is a happy omen, and I cannot help but interpret Bernatius, the Baselians, and the Scaphusians being on our side as a sign of the extraordinary mercy of the Lord. For it seems to me, if I do not mistake, that a firm piety, and a faith that has been acknowledged by us for not so many years, has rooted itself deeper than to be easily overwhelmed by any storms of evil. We experience the same in faithful people of the common provinces, who, although they appear to be stripped of their freedom of learning and, indeed, dragged away and oppressed by tyranny, yet in the midst of affliction stand so erect in mind and do not cease to devise means for supporting their ministers with their own money, that we may openly see that the Word of the Lord, sown into a fruitful ground, cannot but yield its fruit. What remains, then, is that they seem to have attained this with the grace of the Lord, namely the constancy of the city of Zurich, which is in truth our metropolis. Consider how great a scandal would arise from there, if that city, which is strong in men, order, and authority, and which, as a pious mother, has furnished that pure milk of the decayed religion to the other Swiss cities, were to fall from its degree of reception and profession of such great piety, by the force of conspiracies and the arts of evil! For what was granted to their fury for the time in that military covenant does not concern the argument of that faith, since everyone sees that it was forced and woven together by the craftiness of the adversaries, and was done, which usually happens in this kind of deceit, that, what they attempted to confirm by it their own designs in the war, and to weaken ours, we may now easily, by rightly considering the head of that covenant, dissolve the deceit and avoid the calumny, with the assertion of our own religion. But I read with great pleasure your most circumspect advice; and since you ask what I would think was to be done, I answer that I do not think it would be a wise measure to take at the beginning of the business the course which you candidly suggest, since there is hope that they may plainly see that they cannot accomplish what they are attempting, especially since the common people of our country might be affected in various ways, or excited or alienated in mind, with a desire of new things, and a neglect of Swiss liberty, in case we should dissolve the covenants. Besides, I can hardly persuade myself that it will be as you suppose; that, when we shall have renounced the covenants, they will easily keep peace on any terms; but rather I should fear that, by what arts they could, they would, under the pretext of an ancient liberty, and of preserving the name and glory of Switzerland, separate the fields from the cities in general; which they might easily do, if they should make their own people, who are in the country, to appear as if they were ours, after some of the fields had been burnt and laid waste. For you know how faithful some of the country people were lately, that is, in the last war, to the senate of Zurich; to whose (if I may speak freely) perfidy we owe this specious covenant, and acknowledge it to be accepted. Therefore the first thing to be attempted is a more humane and placable way, if perhaps they will yield to humanity and a grave meekness. And if this cannot be attained, then the next way will be to threaten them with the dissolving of the covenants; for to us the covenants, thus open to calumnies, are not covenants, but bonds of our liberty. Who knows but that they may be made tractable by these menaces? For they are not so stupid but that they can consider what evil would arise to them from our departure. But if this counsel could not take effect, then we must take what you advise; namely, to dissolve the covenants for the sake of preserving our liberty; in the meantime to take great care of entering into new alliances and observing them; of obtaining the concord of the cities beyond the Rhine, and the Christian princes; of saluting the French, and of applying to the private fields for aid; to continue faithful; and there to consider the nature of the cause; namely, that, besides losing our ancient liberty, we shall lose that primitive faith and apostolic religion, which is of no greater antiquity, if we would be in league with the pagans. There are many things which, in your sharp judgment, you see more rightly than I could show.

seg.output: I received your letters on the first of December full of consolation, from which I understand that it was thanks to your wisdom that cities agreed to keep the faith and reject the calumnies of the pagans (as Myconius calls them). It certainly is a good omen and I think that Bernatius, from Basilea, and the Scaphusians are showing us a certain extraordinary mercy from the Lord. It seems to me that it signifies that the word of the Lord has planted its roots so deeply that not even the strongest storms can cover it. We also see the same thing in faithful men of the communities, who, although deprived of their freedom, seem to lie and even be taken and oppressed by tyranny, their spirits remain so strong during their afflictions that they still come up with plans to maintain their ministers with their own money, so that we can see that the word of the Lord, planted in fertile ground, cannot fail to bring its fruit. What remains, it seems, is that through the grace of the Lord they have achieved the steadfastness of the city of Zurich, which is in reality our metropolis. Think of what scandal would arise if the city that is so powerful with its men, order and authority, which has given, as a pious mother, this pure milk of a restored religion to the other Swiss cities, would fall from the degree of the received and so strongly professed piety due to the arising conspiracies and storms of malice! For what has been given to their fury in that military treaty is not relevant to the principle of faith, since everyone can see that it was forced and violent, what was then demanded by the cunning of the adversaries, and so it happened, as is usually in this kind of fraud, that, with a proper examination of that treaty, we can now easily avoid the fraud and repel the calumny with the assertion of our religion. I read with great pleasure your most prudent advice; and since you ask what I would think should be done, I respond that it does not seem sensible to me that the first course of action should be the one you hope will happen, so that they can see that their efforts cannot succeed what they are attempting, especially since the people of our country could be affected in various ways and their minds alienated or excited for new arts against us, as those who are greedy for innovations and negligent to the liberty of the Swiss. Furthermore, I hardly believe it will be as you candidly conjecture, that if we renounce the treaties they will easily keep the peace under any conditions; rather I would fear that they will use any means to separate the fields from the cities, under the pretext of maintaining the old freedom and the name and fame of the Swiss, which they could easily do if some fields were burned and troubled, which are rural, and they made their own there, who already seem to be ours. For you know how faithful some of the countryside were to the Senate of Zurich recently, that is in the last war, who, without their goods being taken or troubled, yet dared to separate and make peace with the enemy, I do not know, and to despise the magistrate; of whose (to speak freely) perfidy we owe this so splendid covenant and accept it in return. Therefore, the first thing to be tried is a more human and gentle way, if by chance they give way to humanity and serious gentleness. If that cannot be achieved, then the next way, according to fairness, is to threaten to dissolve the covenant: for us the covenant in this way open to calumnies is not a covenant, but a bond of freedom. Who knows if they will be more tractable to these threats? For they are not so stupid that they cannot understand what evil our departure would bring them. If this plan could not be successful either, then it is necessary to do what you advise: namely, to rescind the covenant for the sake of maintaining our freedom; in the meantime, to be very careful in making and maintaining new friends and allies, to seek the concord of the cities on the other side of the Rhine and the Christian princes, to greet the French, and to ask the private fields to remain faithful; and there to consider the matter of the cause: namely, that we shall not only lose our former freedom, but also the primitive faith and the apostolic religion, which is none older, if we want to be federated with the pagans. There are many things that you see more rightly than I could show, according to your sharp judgment. This will be the last and, as it is said, sacred anchor.

What remains, then, is that they seem to have obtained this through the grace of the Lord, namely, the constancy of the city of Zurich, which is in effect our metropolis. Consider how great a scandal it would be if that city, which is strong with men, order, and authority, and which has been to other Swiss cities as a chaste mother, giving them the pure milk of the restored religion, should fall from its degree of the received and so strongly professed piety, by the storms of conspiracies and evil arts! For that which was granted to their fury for a time in that military league, it does not relate to the consideration of that faith, since it is evident that what was then required by the craftiness of the adversaries was woven and pressed, and so done which is usually observed in this kind of deceit, that, by right considering the head of that league, we may easily dissolve the deceit and decline the calumny, with the assertion of our own religion. I read with great delight your most circumspect counsel; and since you ask what my opinion is of what is to be done, I answer that I do not think it advisable that the same course be taken at the beginning of the business, because there is hope that they will plainly see that they cannot accomplish what they attempt, especially since the people of our nation might be variously affected, or their minds alienated and excited to new arts, as being desirous of novelties and negligent of the liberty of the Swiss. Besides, I can hardly persuade myself that it will be as you candidly conjecture, when we shall have renounced the leagues, that they will easily keep peace upon any terms; but I should rather fear that, by what arts they could, they would dispose the lands widely from the cities, under the pretence of their ancient liberty, and of maintaining the name and glory of the Swiss, which they might easily do, if they should make their own people, who are in the country, by burning and vexing some few districts. For you know what fidelity was lately yielded to the senate of Zurich, that is, in the last war, by some of the country, who, before their goods were taken away or afflicted, yet dared to secede from us, and to make peace with the enemy, and, unknown and contemned the magistrates. To which (to speak freely) we owe this specious league, and thankfully we acknowledge it. Therefore the gentler and more pacifying course should first be attempted, if perchance they would yield to humanity and grave gentleness. If this cannot be obtained, then the next way will be to threaten them of discharging the leagues; for to us the leagues, being thus liable to calumnies, are not leagues, but bonds of our liberty. Who knows whether they may not be made tractable by these threats? For they are not so stupid but that they may consider what evil would ensue to them by our departure. But if this counsel should not prevail, then we must come to that which you propose, namely, that for the maintaining of our liberty we must rescind those leagues, provided that in the meantime great care be taken of entering into and keeping of new friends and allies, of taking concord with the cities beyond the Rhine and Christian princes, of saluting the French, and of asking grants of lands from the private persons, to remain faithful; and there to consider of the cause, namely, that we shall lose not only our ancient liberty, but also our primitive faith and apostolical religion, which is none more ancient, if we will be leagued with the pagans. There are many things which you see more rightly, according to your sharp judgment, than I could show. This shall be the last, and, as it were, sacred anchor. Take care, which you diligently do, that nothing be wanting to the minds of your people for retaining the truth.

seg.output:
I received your letters of the first of December, full of consolation, by which I understand that your wisdom has produced an agreement amongst the cities to remain loyal and to ward off the calumnies of the pagans (as Myconius calls them). Certainly, there is a good omen and I don't know what kind of special mercy of the Lord is shown to us by the help of the Bernese, Baselians and Schaffhausians. For it indicates, if I am not mistaken, that the solid piety and faith which we have acknowledged not too many years ago, and which is based on His word, has taken root more deeply, so that it cannot easily be overcome by any storms of evils. We also experience the same in the faithful men of the common prefectures, who, although they appear to lie and even to be snatched away and oppressed by tyranny through the lack of freedom of teaching, nevertheless stand with firm hearts in the middle of the affliction and do not cease to devise ways to support their ministers from their own money, so that we may see clearly that the word of the Lord, sown in the fertile land, will not fail to yield its fruit. As for the rest, they seem to have attained this by the grace of the Lord, namely the constancy of the city of Zurich, which is in fact our metropolis. Consider what scandal would arise if, which is powerful in men, order and authority, your city, which, like a pious mother, has provided that pure milk of religion which has been drained, should fall from its place of the received and so strongly professed piety because of the rising of conspiracies and storms of evil arts! For what was in the military covenant for the time being given to the fury of those adversaries does not pertain to the point of faith, since everyone can see that it was woven and forced, which then was demanded by the cunning of the adversaries, and thus, that which is usually done in this kind of fraud, that, by rightly inspecting the head of the covenant, we can easily dissolve the fraud and avoid the calumny with the assertion of our religion.
I read with great pleasure your most circumspect advice; and since you ask what I think should be done, I answer that it does not seem to me to be a wise course to take at the beginning of the business that which you hope will make them see that their efforts will not be able to achieve what they are attempting, especially since the common people of our country could be affected in various ways, either getting excited or alienated in spirit, by the new arts against us, as if they were eager for new things and careless of Swiss freedom. Moreover, I hardly persuade myself that it will be as you candidly conjecture, that, when we renounce the covenants, they will easily keep the peace under any conditions; rather, I would fear that by what arts they would give attention to alienating the lands from the cities under the pretext of preserving the old freedom and the name and glory of Switzerland, which they could easily accomplish, if they could provide their own from the countryside, who are already ours, after some fields have been burned and vexed. For you know how faithful to the Senate of Zurich those from the countryside were lately, that is, in the last war, some of whom, though their goods were not yet taken or afflicted, yet dared to withdraw and to make a peace with the enemy, I know not, and to contempt the magistrate. To this perfidy we owe this specious covenant and accept it.
Therefore, the first attempt should be to take a more humane and more conciliatory course, if perhaps they may yield to humanity and grave gentleness. If this cannot be achieved, then the next way will be to threaten them to dissolve the covenants; for to us these covenants, thus open to calumnies, are not covenants of freedom, but bonds. Who knows, if they may not be more tractable to these threats? For they are not so stupid that they cannot consider what evil would come to them from our departure. But if even this plan could not be of service, then this must be done which you advise: namely, for the preservation of our freedom, the covenants must be rescinded; with all vigilance, meanwhile, must be taken to make new and keep friendly allies, to seek the concord of the cities on the other side of the Rhine and of the Christian princes, to salute the French and to ask the private fields, one by one, to remain faithful, and there to consider the kind of cause, namely, that we should not only lose our old freedom, but also our first faith and the apostolic religion, which is none older, if we wish to be covenant with the pagans. There are many things which you see more correctly, by your keen judgment, than I could show. This will be the last and, as it is said, the sacred anchor. Take care, as you are doing diligently, that nothing be taken away from the minds of your people in maintaining the truth. The day will come which will make up, even to the age, whatever loss and damage your republic has suffered from the previous war.

It seems to me, unless I am mistaken, that it indicates that the solid piety, which we have recognized for not too many years, has extended its roots more deeply than can be easily covered by any storm of evil. The same we experience in the faithful men of the common prefectures, who, although they appear deprived of the liberty of doctrine, thrown away and oppressed by tyranny, still stand erect in the midst of affliction and do not cease to devise plans for providing the ministers with their salary, so that we may have evidence that the word of the Lord, sown on a fruitful land, cannot fail to bear fruit. The rest, it seems, they have already obtained through the grace of the Lord, namely, the steadfastness of the city of Zurich, which is in fact our metropolis. Consider, indeed, what scandal would arise if the city of your valor, which with order and authority serves as a pious mother to the other Swiss cities, providing them with the purest milk of the restored religion, should fall from the degree of the received and so strongly professed piety under the storms of plots and bad arts! For what was granted to the violence of their enemies at that time in that military covenant does not pertain to the reason of that faith, since everyone can see that it was composed and forced in such a way that they could confirm their plans in war and weaken ours. Now, by properly examining the head of the covenant, we can easily clear away the fraud and escape the calumny, with the assertion of our own religion.
I read with great pleasure your most careful counsel, and since you ask what I believe should be done, I respond that it does not seem to me to be prudent to take such a course at the beginning of the business, when it is hoped that they will see that they cannot attain what they are aiming for. For this reason also I scarcely believe that it will be as you candidly conjecture, that when we renounce the covenants they will easily keep the peace under any conditions; but rather I would fear that, by what arts soever, they could alienate the people from us, under the pretext of preserving the ancient liberty and the name and glory of the Swiss, by separating the fields from the cities, which they could easily accomplish if they would set fire and vex a few districts, which are in the countryside and seem to be ours. For you know what faith was recently given to the senate of Zurich, that is, in the last war, by certain people from the countryside, who, although their goods were not yet sought out or afflicted, nevertheless dared to withdraw and make peace with the enemy, disregarding the magistrates; and to speak freely, it is to their perfidy that we owe this so beautiful covenant and accept it.
Therefore the first attempt should be made to use more humane and placable methods, if perhaps they would yield to humanity and grave meekness. And if this cannot be accomplished, then the next way will be to threaten them with the dissolution of the covenants, for to us the covenants open to calumny are not covenants of liberty but bonds. Who knows if they will be more tractable at these threats? For they are not so stupid that they cannot consider what evil would result from our departure. But if even this advice could not be successful, then it would remain as you suggest: namely, the rescinding of the covenants for the sake of preserving our liberty, but meanwhile with much vigilance to form new and keep existing friends and allies, to seek agreement with the cities across the Rhine and with Christian princes, to salute the French and to ask private lands to remain faithful, and there to consider the cause, namely, that we would not only lose our ancient liberty, but also the primitive faith and the apostolic religion, which is the most ancient of all, if we should wish to be covenanted with the pagans. There are many things that you see more correctly because of your most acute judgment than I could show. This last will be, as it were, the sacred anchor. Take care, as you diligently do, that nothing be diminished in the spirits of your own in preserving the truth. The day will come which will even repay to this age whatever damage the republic of yours has suffered in the former calamity. Our God is rich and is accustomed to bless even kingdoms those who diligently serve Him. Be secure with respect to the king.

seg.input: V. Kalendas Decembres literas tuas plenas consolationis accepi, ex quibus intelligo, partum esse vestra solertia, ut in fide retinenda et avertendis paganorum (sic eos Myconius vocat) calumniis urbes consentirent. Profecto auspicatum est et nescio quid eximiae miserationis dominicae nobis adumbrat Bernatium, Basileensium, Scaphusianorum auxilium. Significat enim, nisi fallor, solidam pietatem et ipsam non ita multis annis nobis agnitam fidem, quae verbo illius nititur, suas radices altius egisse, quam ut ullis malorum procellis facile queat obrui. Idem in hominibus fidelibus communium praefecturarum experimur, qui, quanquam doctrinae libertate spoliati iacere atque adeo rapti et oppressi tyrannide videantur, in media tamen afflictione sic stant erecti animis nec desinunt de ministris suo aere alendis inire consilia, ut palam videre habeamus, verbum domini in terram frugiferam seminatum non posse non reddere suum fructum. Quod restat igitur, hoc ipsum gratia domini videntur assecuti, nempe constantiam Tigurinae urbis, quae re ipsa nostra metropolis est. Cogita vero, quantum scandali inde nasceretur, si, quae viris, quae ordine, quae auctoritate valet civitas vestra, quaeque ceu pia mater reliquis urbibus Helveticis lac illud purum defecatae religionis praebuit, obortis conspirationum et malarum artium procellis de gradu caderet receptae et tanta cum asseveratione professae pietatis! Nam quod illorum furori pro tempore est in militari illo foedere datum, non attinet ad illius fidei rationem, quum nemo non videat, consuta violentaque esse, quae tunc adversariorum versutia postulavit, atque adeo factum, quod plerumque in hoc doli genere usu venit, ut, quo illi consilia sua in militia confirmare et nostra infirmare tentarunt, eodem consilio iam nunc nos, capite illo foederis recte inspecto, diluere dolum et calumniam declinare cum assertione religionis nostrae facile possimus. Legi vero magna cum voluptate consilium tuum circumspectissimum; et quandoquidem rogas, quid equidem agendum existimarem, respondeo: mihi non videri consultum, ut initio negotii ea ratio ineatur, cum quod spes sit futurum ut illi palam cernant, suos conatus assequi non posse, quod moliuntur, tum maxime, quod ad foederum solutionem vulgus nostrum varie affici et novis artibus adversum nos, ceu rerum novarum cupidis et libertatis Helveticae negligentibus, aut excitari aut alienari animis posset. Praeterea vix mihi persuadeo, id ita fore, quod tu quidem candide coniectas: quum foederibus nos renuntiarimus, pacem illos facile ullis condicionibus servaturos; quin magis id metuerem, quibus possent artibus daturos operam, ut praetextu veteris libertatis et Helvetici nominis atque gloriae retinendae agros passim ab urbibus alienarent, quod quidem bello coepto et alienis adductis auxiliis praesidiisque facile consequerentur, si pagis aliquot exustis et vexatis, qui sunt rure, passim suos facerent, qui iam nostri videntur. Scis enim, quam fidem praestiterint senatui Tigurino nuper, hoc est proximo bello, quidam ex agro, qui rebus suis nondum petitis aut adflictis secedere tamen et cum hoste, nescio et contempto magistratu, pacisci sunt ausi; quorum (ut libere dicam) perfidiae hocce tam speciosum foedus debemus et acceptum referimus. Proinde primum tentanda humaniora et placabilior ratio ineunda, si forte illi humanitati et gravi mansuetudini cedant locum. Ea si assequi nequit, qua ex aequitate est, proxima via erit minitandi, de solvendis scilicet foederibus: nobis enim foedera hoc modo calumniis patentia non foedera, sed vincula esse negat libertatis. Quis scit, an ad has minas fiant tractabiliores? Non enim sunt tam stupidi, quin expendere queant, quid mali illis paritura esset nostra discessio. Quodsi ne hoc quidem consilium posset proficere, tum in hoc esse, quod consulis: nempe nostrae libertatis retinendae gratia foedera illa rescindenda, scilicet interim multa vigilantia de novis ineundis et servandis amicis sociis, de urbium Transrhenanarum et principum Christianorum ambienda concordia, de Gallo salutando ac agris privatis hostiatim rogandis, in fidene mansuri, et inibi de caussae genere: nempe hoc esse in foribus, ut non libertatem modo pristinam, sed et fidem primaevam et religionem apostolicam, qua nulla antiquior est, amissuri simus, si foederati paganis esse velimus. Multa sunt, quae pro tuo acerrimo iudicio rectius vides, quam ego monstrare possem. Haec postrema erit et, quod dicitur, sacra ancora. Cura tantum, id quod sedulo facis, ut animis tuorum nihil decedat ad veritatem retinendam. Veniet dies, quae resarciet etiam saeculo, quicquid damni clade superiori respublica vestra pertulit. Dives est deus noster et se diligentes beare etiam regnis assuevit. De Caesare securi estote. Dimisit magnum militum Germanicorum numerum, nec putant illi aliud esse consilii, quam ut primo vere undis se committat Hispaniis reportandum.
seg.output:
I received your letter on the 1st of December full of consolation, from which I understand that it was due to your wisdom that the cities agreed to hold on to their faith and to avoid the false accusations of the pagans (as Myconius calls them). Certainly it is a good omen and Bernatius, the Basileensians and the Scaphusians seem to be showing us a sign of some extraordinary divine mercy. It appears, if I am not mistaken, that the word of the Lord has taken deeper roots in the solid piety of these people, which we have only come to know in the last few years, so that it cannot be easily overcome by any storm of evil. This is also what we see in the faithful people who are in charge of our common territories, who, although they seem to be deprived of the freedom of doctrine, thrown down and oppressed by tyranny, still stand up with such strength of mind in the middle of their affliction and don't stop making plans to feed their ministers from their own funds, so that we can clearly see that the Lord's word, sown in a fertile land, cannot fail to bring forth its fruit. It seems that we have achieved, by the grace of the Lord, the constancy of the city of Zurich, which is our own metropolis, in fact. Just think of the scandal that would arise if such a city, so powerful in terms of men, order and authority, which has provided that pure milk of a restored religion to the other Swiss cities like a pious mother, were to fall from the position of the faith which it has so firmly professed, in the face of the conspiracy and storms of evil arts! For what has been conceded to their fury in that military agreement does not concern the reason for that faith, since everyone can see that it was a covenant made by force and cunning, which the adversaries demanded at the time, and thus it happened what usually happens in such clever schemes, so that, by looking closely at the head of that agreement, we can easily avoid the fraud and refute the accusations with the assertion of our own religion.
I read your most prudent advice with great pleasure, and, since you ask, what I think should be done, I answer that I do not think it wise to take the course of action at the beginning of the matter, as you hope, so that they will clearly see that they cannot achieve what they are trying to do, especially because of the fact that, with the dissolution of the agreements, the people of our country could be affected in various ways and their minds could be stirred up or estranged from us, who are eager for changes and careless of Swiss liberty. Moreover, I hardly believe that it would be as you kindly suggest: that, if we renounce the agreements, they will easily keep the peace under any conditions; on the contrary, I would fear that they would use any art to alienate the fields from the cities by the pretext of the old liberty and of the Swiss name and glory that must be preserved, which they could easily accomplish, if they set their people in the rural areas, which are already ours, after burning and harassing some of the districts. You know, after all, how faithfull those from the countryside were recently, that is, during the last war, to the Senate of Zurich, that is, some of them, even without their goods being seized or harmed, still dared to leave and make peace with the enemy, ignoring the magistracy; whose (to speak frankly) perfidy we owe this splendid agreement and accept it.
Therefore, the first thing to do is to try a more humane and gentle approach, in case they are open to kindness and seriousness. If this fails, then the next step is to threaten them to dissolve the agreements, since, for us, these agreements, open to calumnies, are not agreements, but chains of liberty. Who knows if they will be more manageable to these threats? For they are not so stupid as not to understand what harm our departure would bring to them. If this advice too could not be successful, then we must do what you suggest: namely, to rescind the agreements in order to preserve our freedom, taking great care at the same time to make and keep new friends and allies, to seek harmony with the cities on the other side of the Rhine and with the Christian princes, to greet the Gauls, to ask for private fields to be guarded in fidelity, and to consider the nature of the case: in other words, we must be aware that, if we want to be allied with the pagans, we will not only lose our ancient freedom, but also our primordial faith and the apostolic religion, which is the oldest of all. There are many things that you can see more correctly from your sharp judgment than I could show. This last one will be, as they say, the sacred anchor. Take care, as you do diligently, that no one of your people move away from the truth. The day will come that will restore to this century whatever losses your republic suffered from the previous disaster. Our God is rich and He loves to bless those who love Him. Be at ease about Caesar. He has sent away a great number of German soldiers and they do not think that any other plan is to be followed but to embark themselves on the sea in the springtime and to be taken to Spain.
